revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
==Incidents== The Mexican organized crime groups often leave multiple bodies in public places as warnings to their rivals; these criminal groups have been fighting for the control of the drug corridors to the United States, the local drug markets in cities, extortion rackets, and human smuggling.<ref>{{cite news|title=49 bodies left on Mexican highway|url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/world/49-bodies-left-on-mexican-highway-20120514-1ylj6.html|accessdate=13 May 2012|newspaper=[[Brisbane Times]]|date=13 May 2012}}</ref> Below are the recent massacres that have occurred in several parts of Mexico between [[Los Zetas]] and the [[Sinaloa Cartel]], who fight to take over each other's territories.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mexican officials report 49 bodies dumped on highway to US border|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/mexican-officials-report-dozens-of-bodies-dumped-on-highway-near-northern-city-of-monterrey/2012/05/13/gIQAP09VMU_story.html|accessdate=13 May 2012|newspaper=[[Washington Post]]|date=13 May 2012}} {{Dead link|date=April 2014|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> The killings are the latest "salvo in a gruesome game of [[tit-for-tat]] in fighting" among Mexican drug cartels.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rodriguez|first=Olga|title=49 headless bodies dumped on north Mexico highway|url=https://news.yahoo.com/49-headless-bodies-dumped-north-mexico-highway-225844950.html|accessdate=14 May 2012|newspaper=Yahoo! News|date=14 May 2012}}</ref>
===2011–2012 Veracruz massacres=== The recent tit-for-tat fighting between Los Zetas and the Sinaloa cartel started in the fall in [[Veracruz]], a strategic smuggling state with a giant gulf port.<ref name=veracruzgulf>{{cite news|title=49 bodies with heads, hands and feet chopped off found on Mexican highway leading to US border|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/49-bodies-with-heads-hands-and-feet-chopped-off-found-on-mexican-highway-leading-to-us-border/2012/05/13/gIQAUVcXNU_story.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120515114504/http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/49-bodies-with-heads-hands-and-feet-chopped-off-found-on-mexican-highway-leading-to-us-border/2012/05/13/gIQAUVcXNU_story.html|archive-date=15 May 2012|accessdate=14 May 2012|newspaper=[[Washington Post]]|date=13 May 2012|deadurl=yes}} </ref> On 20 September 2011, two trucks containing 35 dead bodies were found at an underpass near a shopping mall in [[Boca del Río, Veracruz]].<ref>{{cite news|title=35 bodies found in Mexican roadway during rush hour |url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-09-20/americas/world_americas_mexico-bodies-found_1_bodies-roadway-drug-related-violence?_s=PM:AMERICAS |publisher=CNN |date=20 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011045126/http://articles.cnn.com/2011-09-20/americas/world_americas_mexico-bodies-found_1_bodies-roadway-drug-related-violence?_s=PM%3AAMERICAS |archivedate=11 October 2012 |df= }}</ref> All of the corpses were alleged to be members of [[Los Zetas]],<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=35 muertos de Boca del Río serían Zetas: Autoridades|url=http://www.vanguardia.com.mx/35muertosdebocadelrioserianzetasautoridades-1102898.html|accessdate=11 March 2012|newspaper=[[La Vanguardia]]|date=21 September 2011}}</ref> but it was later proven that only six of them had been involved in minor crime incidents, and none of them were involved with organized crime.<ref name=innocent>{{cite news|last=Martínez |first=Chivis |title=Bodies of Innocents Used as Props in Mexico's Drug War |url=http://www.insightcrime.org/insight-latest-news/item/2742-bodies-of-innocents-used-as-props-in-mexicos-drug-war |accessdate=9 June 2012 |newspaper=InSight Crime |date=8 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120616050357/http://www.insightcrime.org/insight-latest-news/item/2742-bodies-of-innocents-used-as-props-in-mexicos-drug-war |archivedate=16 June 2012 |df= }}</ref> Some of the victims had their hands tied and showed signs of having been tortured.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mexico gunmen abandon two trucks with 35 bodies inside|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-14998500|accessdate=9 May 2012|newspaper=BBC News|date=21 September 2011}}</ref> According to ''[[El Universal (Mexico City)|El Universal]]'', at around 17:00 hours an undetermined number of vehicles blocked a major avenue in Boca del Río.<ref name=eluniversal35>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Veracruz: tiran a 35 ejecutados en zona turística|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/primera/37768.html|accessdate=9 May 2012|newspaper=[[El Universal (Mexico City)|El Universal]]|date=21 September 2011}}</ref> Once the traffic stopped, armed men abandoned two trucks in the middle of the highway.<ref name=eluniversal35/> They opened the doors of the trucks and pulled out the thirty-five corpses, leaving a written message behind.<ref name=eluniversal35/> Other gunmen pointed their weapons at the frightened drivers.<ref name=gunmenpoint>{{cite news|last=Castillo|first=Eduardo|title=Mexico Horror: Suspected Drug Traffickers Dump 35 Bodies On Avenue In Veracruz|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/09/21/mexico-bodies-gunmen_n_973298.html|accessdate=9 May 2012|newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=21 September 2011}}</ref> The cartel members then fled the scene.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Arrojan 35 cuerpos torturados en una calle de Veracruz|url=http://www.elmundo.es/america/2011/09/21/mexico/1316565284.html|accessdate=9 May 2012|newspaper=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]|date=21 September 2011}}</ref>
The ''[[Blog del Narco]]'' reported on 21 September 2011 that the message was supposedly signed by [[Gente Nueva]], an enforcer group that works for [[Joaquín Guzmán Loera]], the top boss of the Sinaloa cartel.<ref>{{cite news|title=35 bodies dumped in Mexican city as president begins effort to woo tourists|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/mexicos-dueling-images-35-dead-in-tourist-town/2011/09/21/gIQAkHjZlK_story.html|accessdate=9 May 2012|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=21 September 2011|first=William|last=Booth}}</ref> Nonetheless, on 27 September 2011, the [[Jalisco New Generation Cartel]] released a video claiming they had carried out these attacks against Los Zetas, and that they were planning to take over Veracruz.<ref name=comandomatazetas>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Comando armado se responsabiliza por cádaveres arrojados en Veracruz|url=http://www.vanguardia.com.mx/comandoarmadoseresponsabilizaporcadaveresarrojadosenveracruz-1108089.html|accessdate=11 March 2012|newspaper=[[La Vanguardia]]|date=27 September 2011}}</ref>
On 6 October 2011 in [[Boca del Río, Veracruz]], 36 bodies were found by the Mexican authorities in three different houses.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Marina reporta el hallazgo de 32 cuerpos en Veracruz; la Procuraduría, 4|url=http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2011/10/06/la-marina-localiza-32-cuerpos-en-casas-de-seguridad-en-veracruz|newspaper=CNN Mexico|date=6 October 2011|access-date=2012-05-14|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120513211541/http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2011/10/06/la-marina-localiza-32-cuerpos-en-casas-de-seguridad-en-veracruz|archive-date=2012-05-13|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The Mexican Navy first discovered 20 bodies inside a house in a residential neighborhood. While searching at another house they found 11 more bodies.<ref name=losangeles36>{{cite news|title=Mexico: 32 Bodies Are Found in Veracruz Houses|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/07/world/americas/mexico-32-bodies-are-found-in-veracruz-houses.html|accessdate=10 May 2012|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=7 October 2011}}</ref> The third and final house contained one body.<ref name=losangeles36/> Four other bodies were confirmed separately by the state government of Veracruz.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Son 36 los cadáveres hallados en Veracruz|url=http://noticierostelevisa.esmas.com/nacional/344731/son-36-cadaveres-hallados-veracruz/|accessdate=10 May 2012|newspaper=[[Televisa]]|date=7 October 2011}}</ref> A day later, Reynaldo Escobar Pérez, the State Justice Attorney General, stepped down and resigned due to the drug-violence.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=El procurador de Veracruz renuncia a su cargo tras una ola de violencia|url=http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2011/10/07/el-procurador-de-veracruz-presenta-su-renuncia-tras-una-ola-de-violencia|accessdate=10 May 2012|newspaper=CNNMéxico|date=7 October 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304040056/http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2011/10/07/el-procurador-de-veracruz-presenta-su-renuncia-tras-una-ola-de-violencia|archive-date=2016-03-04|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> And a day after his resignation, 10 more bodies were found throughout the city of [[Veracruz, Veracruz|Veracruz]].<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|last=Soberanes|first=Rodrigo|title=Otros 10 cadáveres son encontrados en el estado de Veracruz|url=http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2011/10/08/otros-10-cadaveres-son-encontrados-en-el-estado-de-veracruz|accessdate=21 March 2012|newspaper=CNNMéxico|date=8 October 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318000531/http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2011/10/08/otros-10-cadaveres-son-encontrados-en-el-estado-de-veracruz|archive-date=2012-03-18|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The Jalisco New Generation Cartel was also responsible for 67 killings in Veracruz on 7 October 2011.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Caen 'Matazetas' ligados a cadáveres en Veracruz|url=http://noticias.terra.com.mx/mexico/seguridad/caen-matazetas-ligados-a-cadaveres-en-veracruz,808440faee7b3310VgnVCM4000009bf154d0RCRD.html?icid=Publicadores_Links_Relacionados|accessdate=11 March 2012|newspaper=[[Terra Networks]]|date=7 October 2011}}</ref>
On 11 June 2012 in the municipality of [[Álamo, Veracruz]], 14 dismembered bodies were abandoned inside a Nissan truck on a highway near the border with Tamaulipas.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mexican police find 14 bodies in Gulf coast state of Veracruz|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/mexican-police-find-14-bodies-in-gulf-coast-state-of-veracruz/2012/06/12/gJQAoEGtXV_story.html|accessdate=12 June 2012|newspaper=[[Washington Post]]|date=12 June 2012}} {{Dead link|date=April 2014|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> Alerted by an anonymous call, the bodies were found on 8:00 p.m. on June 11, but the authorities finished picking them up at around 7:00 a.m. the next day.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Autoridades hallan 14 cuerpos en los límites de Veracruz y Tamaulipas|url=http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2012/06/12/autoridades-hallan-14-cuerpos-en-los-limites-de-veracruz-y-tamaulipas|accessdate=12 June 2012|newspaper=CNNMéxico|date=12 June 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Fourteen bodies found in eastern Mexico: officials|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jkZglpMB2jNLQwdlC81JxRXmuBVw?docId=CNG.b2371552eed6d000aa85ebc4c2e4bc6b.781|accessdate=13 June 2012|newspaper=[[Agence France-Presse]]|date=12 June 2012}}</ref> Security measures increased in the area after the gruesome discovery.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mexico: 14 bodies found in abandoned truck|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/06/12/world/americas/mexico-bodies-found/index.html|accessdate=13 June 2012|newspaper=[[CNN]]|date=12 June 2012}}</ref>
===2011–2012 Sinaloa massacres=== As a response for the killings in Veracruz, [[Los Zetas]] carried out an incursion to the state of Sinaloa on 23 November 2011 and left 26 bodies — 16 of them burned to death — in several abandoned vehicles in [[Sinaloa]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Mexico Security Memo: Los Zetas Strike in Sinaloa Territory|url=http://www.stratfor.com/analysis/mexico-security-memo-los-zetas-strike-sinaloa-territory|publisher=[[Stratfor]]|accessdate=11 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Las autoridades de Sinaloa localizan 23 cadáveres en tres municipios|url=http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2011/11/23/las-autoridades-de-sinaloa-localizan-20-cadaveres-en-dos-municipios|accessdate=24 November 2011|newspaper=CNN Mexico|date=23 November 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111123204241/http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2011/11/23/las-autoridades-de-sinaloa-localizan-20-cadaveres-en-dos-municipios|archive-date=2011-11-23|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The incident began at early hours of the morning in [[Culiacán]], [[Sinaloa]] with the discovery of a vehicle on fire.<ref name=26sinaloa>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=26 muertos en Sinaloa; 16 fueron calcinados|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/811193.html|accessdate=5 May 2012|newspaper=[[El Universal (Mexico City)|El Universal]]|date=24 November 2011}}</ref> When the police forces managed to put down the flames, they found inside the vehicle a dozen of bodies burned to death, and with wood remains on top of them. All of the victims were handcuffed.<ref name=26sinaloa/> Later on at 07:00 hours, anonymous calls from civilians notified the police that another vehicle in the northern city limits of Culiacán was on fire. The vehicle on fire was a [[Ford Ranger]], and inside were four bodies with bulletproof vests and handcuffed.<ref name=26sinaloa/> During the night, 10 more bodies were found throughout several different municipalities.<ref name=26sinaloa/>
Again in the state of Sinaloa on 5 June 2012, the bodies of 7 men were dumped on a street in [[Culiacán]] inside thirteen plastic bags.<ref name=fox7>{{cite news|title=7 Mutilated bodies found in northwest Mexico|url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/news/2012/06/06/7-mutilated-bodies-found-in-northwest-mexico/|accessdate=9 June 2012|newspaper=[[Fox News]]|date=8 June 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120609075840/http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/news/2012/06/06/7-mutilated-bodies-found-in-northwest-mexico/#|archive-date=2012-06-09|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Initially, the Mexican authorities believed that the victims were police officers because they were wearing similar clothing to those of a special operations unit.<ref name=fox7/> Nonetheless, they concluded that the uniforms were not from any police agency.<ref name=fox7/> A message was left behind by the killers, blaming the Mexican authorities of cooperating with the Sinaloa cartel's drug boss, [[Joaquín Guzmán Loera]], nicknamed ''El Chapo''.<ref>{{cite news|title=7 dismembered bodies found in Mexican Pacific Coast state of Sinaloa|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/7-dismembered-bodies-found-in-mexican-pacific-coast-state-of-sinaloa/2012/06/05/gJQAcqxlGV_story.html|accessdate=9 June 2012|newspaper=[[Washington Post]]|date=5 June 2012}} {{Dead link|date=April 2014|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> The banner accused President [[Felipe Calderón]] and the state authorities for protecting the [[Sinaloa Cartel]].<ref name=cartelgov>{{cite news|last=Fox|first=Edward|title=7 Dead in Sinaloa Alongside Banner Claiming State Collusion With Chapo Guzman|url=http://www.insightcrime.org/insight-latest-news/item/2727-7-dead-in-sinaloa-alongside-banner-claiming-state-collusion-with-chapo-guzman|accessdate=9 June 2012|newspaper=InSight Crime|date=5 June 2012}}</ref> Claims like this are not new to the city of Culiacán; back in 2010 and 2011, banners were put up claiming the state government and police forces protected the Sinaloa cartel.<ref name=cartelgov/> Nonetheless, none of the previous cases involved leaving dead bodies along with the messages, which suggest that the killers are looking to attract more attention of a possible cartel-government collusion.<ref name=cartelgov/>
===2011–2012 Jalisco massacres===
====2011 Guadalajara massacre==== As a response for the Sinaloa cartel incursions, Los Zetas carried out a massacre as a response for the killings done by the ''Matazetas'' against them in the state of [[Veracruz]].<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Ligan al cártel del Milenio-Z con hallazgo de 26 cuerpos en Guadalajara| url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/?p=289106| accessdate=11 March 2012|newspaper=Proceso |date=24 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Guadalajara: Posible guerra Zetas-cartel Sinaloa deja 26 muertos| url=http://mx.noticias.yahoo.com/guadalajara-guerra-zetas-cartel-sinaloa-deja-26-muertos-000102799.html| accessdate=11 March 2012| newspaper=[[Yahoo News]]|date=24 November 2011}}</ref> On 24 November 2011, three trucks containing 26 bodies were found in an avenue at [[Guadalajara, Jalisco]].<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=26 cadáveres son abandonados en camionetas, en una avenida de Guadalajara|url=http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2011/11/24/cadaveres-en-tres-camionetas-son-abandonados-en-un-avenida-de-guadalajara|accessdate=24 November 2011|newspaper=CNN Mexico|date=24 November 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111124202929/http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2011/11/24/cadaveres-en-tres-camionetas-son-abandonados-en-un-avenida-de-guadalajara|archive-date=2011-11-24|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> All of them were male corpses.<ref>{{cite news|title=26 bodies dumped in mass slaying in Guadalajara|url=http://www.chron.com/news/article/26-bodies-dumped-in-mass-slaying-in-Guadalajara-2286984.php|accessdate=24 November 2011|newspaper=[[Houston Chronicle]]}}</ref> At around 7:00 pm, the police station in Guadalajara received numerous anonymous calls from civilians reporting that "several vehicles with more than 10 bodies had been abandoned" in a major avenue.<ref name=eluniversal20>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Hallan al menos 20 cadáveres en Guadalajara|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/811211.html|accessdate=5 May 2012|newspaper=[[El Universal (Mexico City)|El Universal]]|date=24 November 2011}}</ref> Upon the arrival of the police forces, they found a green [[Dodge Caravan#Generation I (1984–1990)|Dodge Caravan]] in the middle lane of the highway, along with a [[Nissan Caravan]] just 66 feet (20 meters) away;<ref name=eluniversal20/> on the farthest right lane was a white Van.<ref name=eluniversal20/> Reports mention that [[Los Zetas]] and the [[Milenio Cartel]] are responsible for the massacre of these twenty-six alleged [[Sinaloa Cartel]] members.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=El Cártel del Milenio y Los Zetas se atribuyen masacre en Guadalajara|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Iw7gOAxgFnI&feature=feedu|accessdate=25 November 2011|newspaper=[[Univision]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Finnegan|first=William|title=THE KINGPINS: The fight for Guadalajara|url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2012/07/02/120702fa_fact_finnegan|accessdate=10 July 2012|newspaper=[[The New Yorker]]|date=2 July 2012}}</ref>
====2012 Chapala massacre==== As a response for the [[2012 Nuevo Laredo massacres]], Los Zetas responded with another massacre of its own.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Suman 18 los muertos encontrados en Chapala, Jalisco: Procuraduría|url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/?p=306918|accessdate=11 May 2012|newspaper=[[Proceso (magazine)|Proceso]]|date=9 May 2012}}</ref><ref name=procurador15>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Descuartizados son en respuesta a los de Nuevo Laredo - Procurador|url=http://www.blogdelnarco.com/2012/05/descuartizados-son-en-respuesta-a-los-de-nuevo-laredo-procurador/|accessdate=10 May 2012|newspaper=[[Blog del Narco]]|date=9 May 2012}}</ref> They left the chopped-up remains of 18 bodies inside a [[Toyota Sienna]] and [[Ford EcoSport]] near the U.S. retiree communities in [[Chapala, Jalisco]], just south of the city of [[Guadalajara]].<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Narcoviolencia vuelve a Jalisco; hallan 18 cuerpos en dos vehículos|url=http://www.excelsior.com.mx/index.php?m=nota&seccion=portada&cat=28&id_nota=833054|accessdate=10 May 2012|newspaper=[[Excélsior]]|date=10 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=At least 15 bodies found near U.S. retiree hamlet in Mexico|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/world_now/2012/05/at-least-15-bodies-found-near-popular-us-retiree-hamlet-in-mexico.html|accessdate=10 May 2012|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=9 May 2012}}</ref><ref name=blogdelnarco15>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Dejan a 15 ejecutados en una camioneta en Jalisco |url=http://www.blogdelnarco.com/2012/05/dejan-a-10-ejecutados-en-una-camioneta-en-jalisco/ |accessdate=9 May 2012 |newspaper=[[Blog del Narco]] |date=9 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120512014601/http://www.blogdelnarco.com/2012/05/dejan-a-10-ejecutados-en-una-camioneta-en-jalisco/ |archivedate=12 May 2012 |df= }}</ref> Eighteen heads were found along the dismembered bodies; some had been frozen, others were covered in lime, and the rest were found in an advance state of decomposition.<ref>{{cite news|last=Looft |first=Christopher |title=With 18 Killed, Zetas Bring Nuevo Laredo War to Jalisco |url=http://insightcrime.org/insight-latest-news/item/2611-with-18-killed-zetas-bring-nuevo-laredo-war-to-jalisco |accessdate=11 May 2012 |newspaper=InSight Crime |date=10 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120518020605/http://insightcrime.org/insight-latest-news/item/2611-with-18-killed-zetas-bring-nuevo-laredo-war-to-jalisco |archivedate=18 May 2012 |df= }}</ref> An anonymous call alerted the police to the abandoned vehicles, which were found by the side of a highway early in the morning on 9 May 2012.<ref name=yahoo15>{{cite news|title=Fifteen decapitated in apparent Mexico revenge attack|url=http://sg.news.yahoo.com/fifteen-decapitated-apparent-mexico-revenge-attack-223203895.html|accessdate=9 May 2012|newspaper=[[Yahoo! News]]|date=9 May 2012}}</ref> They were consequently towed to government offices to unload the bodies.<ref name=guardian15>{{cite news|title=Mexican police discover at least 15 dismembered bodies near Guadalajara|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/may/09/mexico-dismembered-bodies-found-lake-chapala?newsfeed=true|accessdate=9 May 2012|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=9 May 2012|location=London}}</ref> The Mexican authorities confirmed that a message was left behind by the killers, presumably from [[Los Zetas]] and the [[Milenio Cartel]].<ref name=blogdelnarco15/>
===2011–2012 Tamaulipas massacres===
====2011 San Fernando massacre==== {{Main|2011 San Fernando massacre}} The 2011 San Fernando massacre was the mass murder of 193 people by [[Los Zetas]] drug cartel at La Joya ranch in the municipality of [[San Fernando, Tamaulipas|San Fernando]], [[Tamaulipas]], [[Mexico]].<ref name=193muertoz>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Aumenta a 193 los muertos por matanza en San Fernando, Tamaulipas: PGR|url=http://www.milenio.com/cdb/doc/noticias2011/a83771a907f9b3b0aaf6153c163b67ca|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609071102/http://www.milenio.com/cdb/doc/noticias2011/a83771a907f9b3b0aaf6153c163b67ca|dead-url=yes|archive-date=9 June 2011|accessdate=9 March 2012|newspaper=[[Milenio]]|date=7 June 2011}}</ref> Authorities investigating the massacre reported numerous hijackings of passenger buses on [[Mexican Federal Highway 101]] in San Fernando, and the kidnapped victims were later killed and buried in 47 clandestine mass graves.<ref name=193muertoz/> The investigations began immediately after several suitcases and baggage were unclaimed in [[Reynosa]] and [[Matamoros, Tamaulipas]].<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=México: Maletas abandonadas, pista para esclarecer asesinatos en Tamaulipas|url=http://www.terra.com.mx/noticias/articulo/1093197/Mexico+Maletas+abandonadas+pista+para+esclarecer+asesinatos+en+Tamaulipas.htm|accessdate=9 March 2012|newspaper=[[Terra Networks]]|date=19 April 2011}}</ref> On 6 April 2011, the Mexican authorities exhumed 59 corpses from eight mass graves;<ref>{{cite news|last=Chapa|first=Sergio|title=59 bodies found in eight mass graves near San Fernando|url=http://www.valleycentral.com/news/story.aspx?id=602111#.T16VqmK3CFc|accessdate=13 March 2012|newspaper=[[KGBT-TV]]|date=6 April 2011}}</ref> by 7 June 2011, and after a series of multiple excavations, 193 bodies were exhumed from the mass graves in San Fernando.<ref>{{cite news|last=Chapa|first=Sergio|title=San Fernando body count climbs to 193|url=http://www.valleycentral.com/news/story.aspx?id=627152#.T16WOGK3CFc|accessdate=13 March 2012|newspaper=[[KGBT-TV]]|date=7 June 2011}}</ref>
====2012 Nuevo Laredo massacres==== {{Main|2012 Nuevo Laredo massacres}} Dismembered remains of 14 men were found in several plastic bags inside a [[Chrysler Voyager#Generation III|Chrysler Voyager]] in the border city of [[Nuevo Laredo, Tamaulipas|Nuevo Laredo]], [[Tamaulipas]] on 17 April 2012.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mexico authorities say bodies of 14 men dumped in Nuevo Laredo|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/world_now/2012/04/bodies-of-14-men-dumped-in-mexican-border-city.html|accessdate=18 April 2012|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=17 April 2012}}</ref> All of those killed were between the ages of 30 and 35.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Localizan 14 cadáveres dentro de vehículo abandonado en Nuevo Laredo |url=http://www.milenio.com/cdb/doc/noticias2011/667913268f5737dec48f486e722aaf30 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120904062639/http://www.milenio.com/cdb/doc/noticias2011/667913268f5737dec48f486e722aaf30 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=4 September 2012 |accessdate=18 April 2012 |newspaper=[[Milenio]] |date=17 April 2012 }}</ref> Mexican officials stated that they found a "message signed by a criminal group," but they did not release the content of the note,<ref>{{cite news|title=14 mutilated bodies found in Mexican border city |url=http://www.elpasotimes.com/juarez/ci_20419518/14-mutilated-bodies-found-mexican-border-city |accessdate=18 April 2012 |newspaper=[[El Paso Times]] |date=17 April 2012 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> nor if those killed were members of Los Zetas or of the [[Gulf Cartel]].<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|last=Mosso |first=Rubén |title=Nuevo Laredo: hallan 14 cuerpos mutilados |url=http://www.milenio.com/cdb/doc/noticias2011/667913268f5737dec48f486e725f91a7 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130104011548/http://www.milenio.com/cdb/doc/noticias2011/667913268f5737dec48f486e725f91a7 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=4 January 2013 |accessdate=18 April 2012 |newspaper=[[Milenio]] |date=18 April 2012 }}</ref> ''[[CNN en Español|CNNMéxico]]'' stated that the message left behind by the criminal group said that they were going to "clean up Nuevo Laredo" by killing Zeta members.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=14 cuerpos mutilados fueron hallados en Nuevo Laredo|url=http://blogs.cnnmexico.com/ultimas-noticias/2012/04/17/14-cuerpos-mutilados-fueron-hallados-en-nuevo-laredo/|accessdate=18 April 2012|newspaper=[[CNN en Español|CNNMéxico]]|date=17 April 2012}}</ref> ''[[The Monitor (Texas)|The Monitor]]'' newspaper, however, said that a source outside law enforcement but with direct knowledge of the attacks stated the 14 bodies belonged to members of [[Los Zetas]] who had been killed by the Jalisco New Generation Cartel, now a branch of the [[Sinaloa Cartel]].<ref>{{cite news|title=14 bodies found in minivan outside Nuevo Laredo City Hall, according to Tamps. gov't |url=http://www.themonitor.com/articles/bodies-60209-hall-city.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120427034103/http://www.themonitor.com/articles/bodies-60209-hall-city.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=27 April 2012 |accessdate=18 April 2012 |newspaper=[[The Monitor (Texas)|The Monitor]] |date=17 April 2012 }}</ref> Following the attacks, the Sinaloa cartel's kingpin, [[Joaquín Guzmán Loera]]—better known as ''El Chapo Guzmán''—sent a message to [[Los Zetas]] that they will fight for the control of the Nuevo Laredo plaza.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=El Chapo demuestra su poder en Nuevo Laredo, Tamaulipas |url=http://www.blogdelnarco.com/2012/04/el-chapo-demuestra-su-poder-en-nuevo-laredo-tamps/ |accessdate=18 April 2012 |newspaper=[[Blog del Narco]] |date=18 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120420210702/http://www.blogdelnarco.com/2012/04/el-chapo-demuestra-su-poder-en-nuevo-laredo-tamps/ |archivedate=20 April 2012 |df= }}</ref>
23 bodies—14 of them decapitated and 9 of them hanged from a bridge—were discovered in [[Nuevo Laredo, Tamaulipas]], in an escalation of brutal violence involving rival drug gangs on the U.S. border.<ref name=nuevecolgados/> In the first incident, at around 1:00 am on 4 May 2012, nine people were hanged from a bridge on the [[Mexican Federal Highway 85D]] with a message left behind by the killers.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Los cuerpos de 23 personas son encontrados en Nuevo Laredo|url=http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2012/05/04/los-cuerpos-de-23-personas-son-encontrados-en-nuevo-laredo|accessdate=4 May 2012|newspaper=CNNMéxico|date=4 May 2012}}</ref> Horrified motorists encountered the blood-stained bodies of four women and five men hanging off a bridge.<ref>{{cite news|title=23 dead in day of horror for Mexico border city|url=http://au.news.yahoo.com/world/a/-/world/13608544/23-dead-in-day-of-horror-for-mexico-border-city/|accessdate=4 May 2012|newspaper=[[Yahoo! News]]|date=4 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120516195543/http://au.news.yahoo.com/world/a/-/world/13608544/23-dead-in-day-of-horror-for-mexico-border-city/|archive-date=2012-05-16|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The banner left behind reportedly stated that those killed were the perpetrators of the car bomb in the city on 24 April 2012.<ref name=nuevecolgados>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Nuevo Laredo vive un viernes negro, jornada violenta deja 23 muertos|url=http://excelsior.com.mx/index.php?m=nota&seccion=seccion-nacional&cat=1&id_nota=831656|accessdate=4 May 2012|newspaper=[[Excélsior]]|date=4 May 2012}}</ref> In addition, the 9 people who were hanged on the bridge were reportedly members of the [[Gulf Cartel]] who were killed by [[Los Zetas]] for "heating up" their turf.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Suman 23 muertos en Nuevo Laredo, entre colgados y decapitados|url=http://noticias.univision.com/narcotrafico/noticias/article/2012-05-04/nueve-cuerpos-colgados-puente-nuevo-laredo-mexico-narco-zetas#axzz1tvkHuxlD|accessdate=4 May 2012|newspaper=[[Univision]]|date=4 May 2012}}</ref> In the second incident, which occurred hours later, 14 decapitated bodies were abandoned inside a vehicle in front of the Customs Agency;<ref name=universal23/> the severed heads were left inside several ice coolers in front of the municipal palace.<ref name=universal23>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Van 23 muertos en Nuevo Laredo, en ola de violencia|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/845350.html|accessdate=4 May 2012|newspaper=[[El Universal (Mexico City)|El Universal]]|date=4 May 2012}}</ref> The Mexican police said the second massacre could have been an act of revenge by the [[Gulf Cartel]] to Los Zetas for the earlier killings.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bodies of 23 found dumped near U.S. border in Mexico drug war|url=https://news.yahoo.com/nine-bodies-hung-bridge-northern-mexico-174942376.html|accessdate=4 May 2012|newspaper=[[Yahoo! News]]|date=4 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Se recrudece violencia en Nuevo Laredo: 23 muertos|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/estados/85705.html|accessdate=5 May 2012|newspaper=[[El Universal (Mexico City)|El Universal]]|date=5 May 2012}}</ref> Along with the decapitated bodies was a message allegedly signed by [[Joaquín Guzmán Loera]], where he demanded the municipality mayor of [[Nuevo Laredo]], Benjamín Galván, along with other municipal and state leaders and public safety officials to recognize the Sinaloa cartel's presence in the area and stop insisting he is not in the city.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Pide "El Chapo Guzman" al alcalde de Nuevo Laredo que deje de negar su presencia|url=http://www.lapoliciaca.com/nota-roja/pide-el-chapo-guzman-al-alcalde-de-nuevo-laredo-que-deje-de-negar-su-presencia/|accessdate=6 May 2012|newspaper=La Policiaca|date=6 May 2012}}</ref>
==== 2012 Ciudad Mante massacres==== In the afternoon of 7 June 2012 just outside city hall of [[Ciudad Mante, Tamaulipas]], 14 mutilated bodies were discovered inside a parked truck.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mexico: 14 dismembered bodies found outside city hall|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/06/08/world/americas/mexico-bodies-found/index.html|accessdate=9 June 2012|newspaper=[[CNN]]|date=8 June 2012}}</ref> Investigators stated that the bodies were of 11 men and 3 women. The bodies are accompanied by a banner taking credit for the killings.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dismembered bodies of 14 reported dumped in northern Mexico|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/world_now/2012/06/dismembered-bodies-of-14-dumped-in-northern-mexican-state.html|accessdate=9 June 2012|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=8 June 2012}}</ref> Although unconfirmed, according to the ''[[Proceso (magazine)|Proceso]]'' magazine, the banner was signed by the [[Sinaloa Cartel]] and directed to Los Zetas, an organized crime group that currently controls the drug trafficking corridor of Ciudad Mante.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Documentan en Youtube narcoviolencia en Tamaulipas|url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/?p=310563|accessdate=12 June 2012|newspaper=[[Proceso (magazine)|Proceso]]|date=11 June 2012}}</ref> ''[[Milenio]]'' confirmed that the [[Gulf Cartel]] had killed the 14 people, allegedly members of Los Zetas, as retaliation for the grenade attacks they had carried out in [[Matamoros, Tamaulipas]], the headquarters of the Gulf cartel.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|last=Mosso|first=Rubén|title=Ataques en Matamoros para afectar al Cártel del Golfo: Sedena|url=http://www.milenio.com/cdb/doc/noticias2011/608664688e3a6100209d709e4086f3fc|accessdate=14 June 2012|newspaper=[[Milenio]]|date=14 June 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120617023336/http://www.milenio.com/cdb/doc/noticias2011/608664688e3a6100209d709e4086f3fc|archive-date=2012-06-17|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The ''[[Blog del Narco]]'' uploaded a [https://web.archive.org/web/20130419024407/http://www.blogdelnarco.com/2012/06/video-abandonan-camion-con-14-descuartizados-en-tamaulipas/ video] on their website from an anonymous cameraman who filmed the truck and the fourteen corpses.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Video: Abandonan camión con 14 descuartizados en Tamaulipas |url=http://www.blogdelnarco.com/2012/06/video-abandonan-camion-con-14-descuartizados-en-tamaulipas/ |accessdate=28 June 2012 |newspaper=[[Blog del Narco]] |date=27 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130419024407/http://www.blogdelnarco.com/2012/06/video-abandonan-camion-con-14-descuartizados-en-tamaulipas/ |archivedate=19 April 2013 |df= }}</ref>
In response to the Gulf cartel attacks, [[Los Zetas]] responded in their kind, leaving 14 mutilated bodies inside an abandoned bus on a parking lot of a shopping center in Ciudad Mante.<ref name=14mante2>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Hallan 14 cuerpos mutilados en centro comercial de Tamaulipas, México|url=http://noticias.univision.com/narcotrafico/noticias/article/2012-06-23/14-cuerpos-mutilados-tamaulipas#axzz1yjehyFjr|accessdate=24 June 2012|newspaper=[[Univision]]|date=23 June 2012}}</ref> The bodies of ten men and four women, which were reported at around 9 a.m. on 23 June 2012, were left behind along with a banner directed to the Gulf cartel.<ref name=14mante2/> Its message, however, was not revealed by the Mexican authorities.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Abandonan camión con 14 cuerpos mutilados en Cd. Mante, Tamaulipas|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/ultimas/2012/06/23/14597952-dejan-14-cuerpos-mutilados-en-estacionamiento-en-tamaulipas|accessdate=24 June 2012|newspaper=[[La Jornada]]|date=23 June 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120625003530/http://www.jornada.unam.mx/ultimas/2012/06/23/14597952-dejan-14-cuerpos-mutilados-en-estacionamiento-en-tamaulipas|archive-date=2012-06-25|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> This gruesome discovery happened a day after several grenade attacks in the capital city of [[Ciudad Victoria, Tamaulipas]], where eight people were injured.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Dejan camión con 14 cadáveres mutilados en estacionamiento, en Tamaulipas|url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/?p=311870|accessdate=24 June 2012|newspaper=[[Proceso (magazine)|Proceso]]|date=23 June 2012}}</ref>
Ciudad Mante is a sugar-cane growing community with a population of near 110,000 people, located just 250 miles south from [[Texas]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Chapa|first=Sergio|title=14 dismembered bodies left in front of Ciudad Mante City Hall|url=http://www.valleycentral.com/news/story.aspx?id=763252#.T9KnT-JYvDE|accessdate=9 June 2012|newspaper=[[KGBT-TV]]|date=8 June 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=14 mutilated bodies found in Mexico|url=http://www.skynews.com.au/world/article.aspx?id=759142&vId=|accessdate=9 June 2012|newspaper=[[Sky News]]|date=8 June 2012}}</ref>
===2011–2012 Nuevo León massacres===
====2012 Apodaca prison riot==== {{Main|Apodaca prison riot}} On 19 February 2012 at a prison in [[Apodaca]], [[Nuevo León]], Mexico,<ref name=AlJazeera>{{cite news|title=Dozens killed in Mexico prison fight|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/americas/2012/02/2012219165349443681.html|accessdate=19 February 2012|publisher=Al Jazeera}}</ref> at least 44 people were killed, with another twelve injured.<ref name=AlJazeera /> The ''[[Blog del Narco]]'', a blog that documents events and people of the [[Mexican Drug War]] anonymously, reported that the actual (unofficial) death toll may be more than 70 people.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Motín en Nuevo León: oficial 38 reos muertos, extraoficial al menos 70 |url=http://www.blogdelnarco.com/2012/02/motin-en-nuevo-leon-oficial-20-reos-muertos-extraoficial-al-menos-70/ |accessdate=19 February 2012 |newspaper=Blog del Narco |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222214523/http://www.blogdelnarco.com/2012/02/motin-en-nuevo-leon-oficial-20-reos-muertos-extraoficial-al-menos-70/ |archivedate=22 February 2012 |df= }}</ref> The fight was between [[Los Zetas]] and the [[Gulf Cartel]], two drug cartels that operate in northeastern Mexico.<ref>{{cite news|title=Drug cartel blamed in prison riot that killed 44|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2012/02/20/MNKU1NA3UD.DTL|accessdate=21 February 2012|newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]}}</ref> The governor of [[Nuevo León]], [[Rodrigo Medina]], mentioned on 20 February 2012 that 30 inmates escaped from the prison during the riot.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Funcionarios, cómplices en fuga de 30 reos en Apodaca, dice el gobernador|url=http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2012/02/20/funcionarios-complices-en-fuga-de-30-reos-en-apodaca-dice-el-gobernador|accessdate=20 February 2012|newspaper=CNNMexico|date=20 February 2012}}</ref> Four days later, however, the new figures of the fugitives went down to 29.<ref name=29fugitives>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Son 29 fugados de Apodaca, rectifica PGJNL|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/832367.html|accessdate=25 February 2012|newspaper=[[El Universal (Mexico City)|El Universal]]|date=24 February 2012}}</ref> On 16 March 2012, the Attorney General's Office of Nuevo León confirmed that 37 prisoners had actually escaped on the day of the massacre.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Del penal de Apodaca se fugaron 37 reos, no 29, corrigen las autoridades|url=http://www.animalpolitico.com/2012/03/del-penal-de-apodaca-se-fugaron-37-reos-no-29-corrigen-las-autoridades/|accessdate=18 March 2012|newspaper=Animal Politico|date=16 March 2012}}</ref> One of the fugitives, Óscar Manuel Bernal alias ''La Araña'' (The Spider), is considered by the Mexican authorities to be "extremely dangerous," and is believed to be the leader of [[Los Zetas]] in the municipality of [[Monterrey (municipality)|Monterrey]].<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Reo fugado en NL, de alta peligrosidad|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/831322.html|accessdate=20 February 2012|newspaper=El Universal}}</ref> Some other fugitives were also leaders in the organization.<ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Eran ex jefes de plaza algunos de los fugados|url=http://monterrey.milenio.com/cdb/doc/noticias2011/46f44ba7e588e26323fddb22c6a22261|accessdate=30 March 2012|newspaper=[[Milenio]]|date=21 February 2012}}</ref>
====2012 Cadereyta Jiménez massacre==== {{Main|Cadereyta Jiménez massacre}} On 13 May 2012 on the [[Mexican Federal Highway 40]] in the municipality of Cadereyta Jiménez, 49 people were [[decapitated]] and mutilated by members of [[Los Zetas]] drug cartel and dumped by a roadside near the city of [[Monterrey]] in northern Mexico.<ref name=yahoo1>{{cite news |title=Official: 49 bodies left on Mexico highway |url=https://news.yahoo.com/official-49-bodies-left-mexico-highway-153421616.html |accessdate=13 May 2012 |newspaper=[[Yahoo! News]] |date=13 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Mexico violence: Monterrey police find 49 bodies |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-18052540 |accessdate=13 May 2012 |newspaper=BBC News |date=13 May 2012}}</ref> The bodies were found in the town of San Juan in the municipality of [[Cadereyta Jiménez, Nuevo León]], at about 4 a.m. on a non-toll highway leading to [[Reynosa, Tamaulipas]].<ref>{{cite news|title=49 bodies dumped on Mexican highway|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-202_162-57433360/49-bodies-dumped-on-mexican-highway/|accessdate=13 May 2012|newspaper=[[CBS News]]|date=13 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{es icon}} {{cite news|title=Autoridades hallan 49 cadáveres en una carretera de Nuevo León|url=http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2012/05/13/autoridades-hallan-49-cadaveres-en-una-carretera-de-nuevo-leon|accessdate=13 May 2012|newspaper=[[CNN en Español|CNNMéxico]]|date=13 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120513165104/http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2012/05/13/autoridades-hallan-49-cadaveres-en-una-carretera-de-nuevo-leon|archive-date=2012-05-13|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The forty-three men and six women killed had their heads, feet, and hands cut off, making their identification difficult.<ref name=yahoo1/> Those killed also bore signs of torture and were stuffed in plastic bags.<ref>{{cite news|title=49 bodies left on Mexican highway|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/49-bodies-left-on-mexican-highway-20120514-1ylj6.html|accessdate=13 May 2012|newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=13 May 2012}}</ref> Four days before this incident, 18 people were found decapitated and dismembered near Mexico's second largest city, [[Guadalajara]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Scores of mutilated bodies dumped on Mexico highway|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-18053841|accessdate=14 May 2012|newspaper=BBC News|date=13 May 2012}}</ref> The discovery seems to echo several other mass murder events where the drug cartels have left large numbers of bodies in public places as warnings to their rivals.<ref>{{cite news|title=Discovery of mutilated bodies shuts down Reynosa, Monterrey highway|url=http://www.valleycentral.com/news/story.aspx?id=753239#.T7AXZJ9YvDE|accessdate=13 May 2012|newspaper=[[KGBT-TV]]|date=13 May 2012}}</ref> The authorities have blamed much of the violence on Los Zetas – a cartel originally set up by ex-commandos that deserted the Mexican Army in the 1990s – and the [[Sinaloa Cartel]], an organization headed by [[Joaquín Guzmán Loera]] (a.k.a. ''El Chapo''), Mexico's [[List of Mexico's 37 most-wanted drug lords|most-wanted drug lord]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Mexican police find 49 mutilated bodies |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jOev2gv924y-rr5TfL0gdsKK2D9Q?docId=CNG.b969947e3b77f22abb01eefd55bf92b6.451 |accessdate=13 May 2012 |agency=Agence France-Presse |date=13 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Dozens of bodies found in bags |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/ipad/dozens-of-bodies-found-in-bags/story-fn6s850w-1226354397712 |accessdate=14 May 2012 |newspaper=[[Herald Sun]] |date=13 May 2012}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of massacres in Mexico]] * [[Infighting in the Gulf Cartel]] * [[Mexican Drug War]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/17/magazine/how-a-mexican-drug-cartel-makes-its-billions.html?_r=1 Cocaine Incorporated] – ''[[New York Times]]'' *[http://projects.latimes.com/mexico-drug-war/#/its-a-war Mexico Under Siege: The drug war at our doorstep] – ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''
{{Mexican Drug War|state=collapsed}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:2011-12 in the Mexican Drug War}} [[Category:2011 in Mexico]] [[Category:2012 in Mexico]] [[Category:Timelines of military conflicts since 1945|Mexican Drug War]] [[Category:Mexican Drug War]] [[Category:Organized crime conflicts in Mexico| ]] [[Category:Chronology of wars|Mexican Drug War]]

{{Infobox film | name = Alice Cooper a Paris | image = Alice Cooper a Paris Screenshot.jpg | caption = Title Screen | director = [[Agnès Delarive]] | producer = | writer = [[Agnès Delarive]] | music = [[Alice Cooper]] | cinematography= [[Thierry Malaterre]] | editing = | starring = ''[[Alice Cooper]]
[[Sheryl Cooper]]
[[Duane Hitchings]]
[[John Nitzinger]]
[[Mike Pinera]]
[[Erik Scott]]
[[Jan Uvena]] | country = | runtime = 46 minutes | language = English, French | distributor = | released = {{Film date|1982|01|14|France}} }} '''''Alice Cooper a Paris''''' (more commonly known as ''Alice in Paris''{{cite book|last=Sherman|first=Dale |title=The Illustrated Collector's Guide to Alice Cooper, 10th Anniversary Edition|publisher=Collector's Guide Publishing, Inc.|year=2009|pages=209|isbn=978-1-894959-93-3}}) is a French television special starring shock-rocker [[Alice Cooper]]. A series of music videos of songs from his then-current album ''[[Special Forces (Alice Cooper album)|Special Forces]]'' with a few songs from ''[[Flush the Fashion]]'' and some older hits mixed in, several songs were re-recorded for the special{{cite book|last=Sherman|first=Dale |title=The Illustrated Collector's Guide to Alice Cooper, 10th Anniversary Edition|publisher=Collector's Guide Publishing, Inc.|year=2009|pages=210|isbn=978-1-894959-93-3}} ("[[Only Women Bleed]]", "[[I'm Eighteen]]", "[[Billion Dollar Babies (song)|Billion Dollar Babies]]", "[[School's Out (song)|School's Out]]") and have shown up as B-sides of singles with crowd noises mixed in to give the illusion that they were live recordings. The songs are performed in English, but one brief [[Split screen (filmmaking)|split-screen]] sketch features French dialogue as radio disc jockey Vincent Furnier (Cooper's real name) interviews Alice. There has never been an official release and, while not officially broadcast outside France,{{cite web|url=http://www.sickthingsuk.co.uk/television/tv-paris.php|title=Alice in Paris|accessdate=2009-12-02}} copies have been circulating amongst Alice Cooper fans for decades. Some copies are missing opening credits, leading fans to refer to it under a variety of titles, including ''Alice in Paris'', ''The Paris Special'' and ''16 Tracks''. ==Track listing== # "[[You and Me (Alice Cooper song)|You and Me]]" (partial) # "Generation Landslide '81" # "[[Under My Wheels]]" # "[[Clones (We're All)]]" # "Pain" # "[[7 and 7 Is|Seven and Seven Is]]" # "Prettiest Cop on the Block" # "Model Citizen" # "Cold Ethyl" # "[[Only Women Bleed]]" # "Go to Hell" # "Who Do You Think We Are?" # "Vicious Rumours" # "[[I'm Eighteen]]" # "[[Billion Dollar Babies (Alice Cooper song)|Billion Dollar Babies]]" # "[[School's Out (song)|School's Out]]" # "Who Do You Think We Are? (reprise)" ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{imdb title|id=0218810|title=Alice Cooper à Paris}} *[http://graphikdesigns.free.fr/alice_cooper_french_tv.html Alice Cooper Special Forces in Paris DVD] {{Alice Cooper}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Alice Cooper A Paris}} [[Category:Alice Cooper]] [[Category:Music television specials]]

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Wataru Inoue]] (link changed to [[Wataru Inoue (wrestler)]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
[[File:All Together Puroresu.png|thumb|Logo of the All Together events]] '''All Together''' was a series of two [[professional wrestling]] events organized together by [[Japan]]'s three biggest [[Professional wrestling promotion|promotions]]; [[All Japan Pro Wrestling]] (AJPW), [[New Japan Pro-Wrestling]] (NJPW) and [[Pro Wrestling Noah]], in response to the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|March 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]]. The first event was held in [[Tokyo]] on August 27, 2011, and the second in [[Sendai]] on February 19, 2012. All proceeds from the events were donated to [[Japanese Red Cross]]. The events featured no [[Narrative thread|storylines]] or [[Championship (professional wrestling)|championship]] matches, instead they were [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Book|booked]] as "[[Card (sports)#Supercard|supercards]]", putting together combinations of wrestlers from the three promotions that fans would normally not see. ==Tokyo== {{Infobox wrestling event |name=All Together |image= |caption= |tagline= |theme="All Together" by [[Funkist]] |promotion=[[All Japan Pro Wrestling]]
[[New Japan Pro-Wrestling]]
[[Pro Wrestling Noah]] |date=August 27, 2011 |attendance=17,000 |venue=[[Nippon Budokan]] |city=[[Tokyo]] |lastevent=(AJPW) 2011 Puroresu Love in Ryōkoku Vol. 12
(NJPW) [[G1 Climax#2011|G1 Climax 2011]]
(Noah) New Navigation '10 in Osaka |nextevent=(AJPW/Noah) [[#Sendai|All Together: Mōikkai, Hitotsu ni Narō ze]]
(NJPW) G1 Climax Special 2011 }} On April 18, 2011, Yukinobu Ebata, president of the ''[[Tokyo Sports]]'' magazine, [[All Japan Pro Wrestling]] president [[Keiji Mutoh]] and [[Triple Crown Heavyweight Championship|top champion]] [[Kohei Suwama|Suwama]], [[New Japan Pro-Wrestling]] president Naoki Sugabayashi and [[IWGP Heavyweight Championship|top champion]] [[Hiroshi Tanahashi]] and [[Pro Wrestling Noah]] president [[Akira Taue]] and [[GHC Heavyweight Championship|top champion]] [[Takashi Sugiura]] held a press conference in [[Tokyo]]'s [[Nippon Budokan]], announcing that the three promotions would be coming together for a charity event on August 27 at the same arena.{{cite web | url = http://www.all-together.jp/news/20110418.html?width=850&height=450 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110507221908/http://www.all-together.jp/news/20110418.html?width=850&height=450 | title = プロレスで元気を！ 新日本＆全日本＆ノアが「東日本大震災復興支援チャリティープロレス All Together」を開催！ | archivedate=May 7, 2011 | date=April 18, 2011 | accessdate=September 8, 2013 | work=All Together | language=Japanese}}{{cite web | url = http://www.nikkansports.com/battle/news/f-bt-tp0-20110418-763013.html | script-title=ja:新日本＋全日本＋ノア＝８月慈善マッチ | date=April 18, 2011 | accessdate=September 8, 2013 | work=[[Nikkan Sports]] | language=Japanese}}{{cite web | url = http://sportsnavi.yahoo.co.jp/fight/headlines/20110418-00000016-spnavi-fight.html | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110423055446/http://sportsnavi.yahoo.co.jp/fight/headlines/20110418-00000016-spnavi-fight.html | script-title=ja:新日・全日・ノアがチャリティー興行で団結　32年ぶり夢のオールスター実現 | archivedate=April 23, 2011 | date=April 18, 2011 | accessdate=September 8, 2013 | work=Sports Navi | publisher=[[Yahoo!]] | language=Japanese}} All proceeds from the event would be donated to help those affected by the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|March 11, 2011, Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]]. The event marked the first time all three promotions had come together to co-produce an event and the first time since August 1979, when AJPW and NJPW had co-produced an event. The event was sponsored by ''Tokyo Sports''. Rock band [[Funkist]] composed a song named "All Together" for the event, which featured thirty wrestlers from the three promotions singing backing vocals.{{cite web | url = http://www.daily.co.jp/ring/2011/06/10/0004156196.shtml | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110814160028/http://www.daily.co.jp/ring/2011/06/10/0004156196.shtml | script-title=ja:被災地思い３団体30人集結！魂の激唱 | archivedate=August 14, 2011 | date=June 10, 2011 | accessdate=September 8, 2013 | work=Daily Sports Online | publisher=[[Kobe Shimbun]] | language=Japanese}}{{cite web | url = http://www.nikkansports.com/battle/news/f-bt-tp0-20110610-787970.html | script-title=ja:新日本、全日本、ノア選手30人支援ソング | date=June 10, 2011 | accessdate=September 8, 2013 | work=[[Nikkan Sports]] | language=Japanese}} The event aired live on [[pay-per-view]],{{cite web | url = http://www.all-together.jp/news/20110715-2.html?width=850&height=450 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110721053001/http://www.all-together.jp/news/20110715-2.html?width=850&height=450 | title = あなたの購入したPPVがチャリティーになります！「All Together」をスカパー！でPPV完全生中継!! | archivedate=July 21, 2011 | date=July 15, 2011 | accessdate=September 8, 2013 | work=All Together | language=Japanese}} and was later aired on [[Broadcast delay|tape delay]] on Fighting TV Samurai, Gaora, NTV G+ and [[TV Asahi]].{{cite web | url = http://www.all-together.jp/news/20110715-1.html?width=850&height=450 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110721052955/http://www.all-together.jp/news/20110715-1.html?width=850&height=450 | title = テレビ中継も「All Together」!!　テレビ朝日&日本テレビ&Gaora&サムライTVで8.27日本武道館大会を視聴しよう！ | archivedate=July 21, 2011 | date=July 15, 2011 | accessdate=September 8, 2013 | work=All Together | language=Japanese}} In addition to AJPW, NJPW and Noah wrestlers, [[Kota Ibushi]] from [[DDT Pro-Wrestling]] and [[Kensuke Sasaki]], [[Katsuhiko Nakajima]], [[Kento Miyahara]] and Satoshi Kajiwara from [[Diamond Ring (professional wrestling)|Kensuke Office]] also took part in the event. [[Americans|American]] retired wrestler [[Dick Beyer]], using his famous The Destroyer [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Gimmick|character]], attended the event and presented a trophy to the winner of the Destroyer Cup.{{cite web | url = http://www.njpw.co.jp/match/detail_result_game.php?e=276&c=3266 | title = 東日本大震災復興支援チャリティープロレス　「All Together」 | accessdate=September 8, 2013 | work=[[New Japan Pro-Wrestling]] | language=Japanese}} [[Manabu Nakanishi]] and [[Satoshi Kojima]] from NJPW and [[Naomichi Marufuji]] and [[Takeshi Rikio]] from Noah were forced to miss the event due to injuries. All in all, the event featured ten matches involving 82 wrestlers.{{cite web | url = http://sportsnavi.yahoo.co.jp/sports/fight/all/2012/columndtl/201108270001-spnavi | title = 棚橋、諏訪魔、潮崎が「被災地に元気を」と意気込み＝All Together メーンは『ビチッ』と"Kensoワールド"さく裂か!? | date=August 27, 2011 | accessdate=September 8, 2013 | work=Sports Navi | publisher=[[Yahoo!]] | language=Japanese}} The semi-main event, where AJPW wrestler Keiji Mutoh and Noah wrestler [[Kenta Kobashi]] defeated the NJPW [[tag team]] of [[Takashi Iizuka]] and [[Toru Yano]], was later named the 2011 [[Tokyo Sports Puroresu Awards#Best Bout Award|Match of the Year]] by ''Tokyo Sports''.{{cite web | url = http://www.tokyo-sports.co.jp/prores/61356/ | script-title=ja:日本列島に夢と感動と希望を与えた武藤＆小橋のムーンサルトプレス | date=December 15, 2011 | accessdate=September 8, 2013 | work=[[Tokyo Sports]] | language=Japanese}} On October 25, representatives of the three promotions handed a check of [[Japanese yen|¥]]58,273,560, made up of ticket, PPV and merchandise sales, to [[Japanese Red Cross]].{{cite web | url = http://www.njpw.co.jp/news/detail.php?nid=6541 | title = 『All Together』義援金、5,827万円を赤十字社へ!! 棚橋、潮崎、カズ、3団体の代表選手が贈呈!! | date=October 25, 2011 | accessdate=September 8, 2013 | work=[[New Japan Pro-Wrestling]] | language=Japanese}}{{cite web | url = http://www.nikkansports.com/battle/news/f-bt-tp0-20111025-854682.html | script-title=ja:プロレス３団体が義援金5800万円寄付 | date=October 25, 2011 | accessdate=September 8, 2013 | work=[[Nikkan Sports]] | language=Japanese}} ===Results=== {{Pro Wrestling results table |hide=all |results={{cite web | url = http://www.all-japan.co.jp/schedule/tour03.php?taikai_id=162 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110903155336/http://www.all-japan.co.jp/schedule/tour03.php?taikai_id=162 | title = 東日本大震災復興支援チャリティープロレス　『All Together』 | archivedate=September 3, 2011 | accessdate=September 8, 2013 | work=[[All Japan Pro Wrestling]] | language=Japanese}}{{cite web | url = http://www.njpw.co.jp/match/detail_result.php?e=276 | title = 東日本大震災復興支援チャリティープロレス　「All Together」 | accessdate=September 8, 2013 | work=[[New Japan Pro-Wrestling]] | language=Japanese}}{{cite web | url = http://www.noah.co.jp/result.php?tour_id=805 | title = 東日本大震災復興支援チャリティープロレス「All Together」 | accessdate=September 8, 2013 | work=[[Pro Wrestling Noah]] | language=Japanese}}{{cite web | url = http://sportsnavi.yahoo.co.jp/fight/other/live/2011/2011082701/index.html | archiveurl = Machine]], [[Masao Inoue]], [[Gedo (wrestler)|Gedo]].{{refend}} ==Sendai== {{Infobox wrestling event |name=All Together:
Mōikkai, Hitotsu ni Narō ze |image= |caption= |tagline= |theme="All Together" by [[Funkist]] |promotion=[[All Japan Pro Wrestling]]
[[New Japan Pro-Wrestling]]
[[Pro Wrestling Noah]] |date=February 19, 2012 |attendance=3,500 |venue=[[Sendai Sun Plaza|Sendai Sun Plaza Hall]] |city=[[Sendai]], [[Miyagi Prefecture|Miyagi]] |lastevent=(AJPW/Noah) [[#Tokyo|All Together]]
(NJPW) [[The New Beginning (2012)]] |nextevent=(NJPW) Hataage Kinenbi (2012)
(Noah) [[Final Burning in Budokan]] }} The second All Together show, subtitled ''Mōikkai, Hitotsu ni Narō ze'' ("Once More, Let's Become One"), was announced at the conclusion of the first show.{{cite web | url = http://www.njpw.co.jp/match/detail_result_game2.php?e=276&c=3271 | title = 東日本大震災復興支援チャリティープロレス　「All Together」 | accessdate=September 8, 2013 | work=[[New Japan Pro-Wrestling]] | language=Japanese}} It was held on February 19, 2012, at the [[Sendai Sun Plaza|Sendai Sun Plaza Hall]] in [[Sendai]], [[Miyagi Prefecture|Miyagi]], which was the nearest major city to the epicenter of the March 11, 2011, earthquake and suffered major damage in it and the following tsunami.{{cite web|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eqinthenews/2011/usc0001xgp/ |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xgj6FuHC?url=http://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eqinthenews/2011/usc0001xgp/ |title=Magnitude 9.03 – Near the East Coast of Honshu, Japan |archivedate=April 4, 2011 |accessdate=September 8, 2013 |work=[[United States Geological Survey]] |deadurl=yes |df= }} Much like the first All Together, the second one also aired live on pay-per-view and on tape delay on Fighting TV Samurai, Gaora, NTV G+ and TV Asahi.{{cite web | url = http://www.njpw.co.jp/news/detail.php?nid=7067 | title = テレビ朝日、G+、Gaora、サムライ、CSテレ朝!!　「All Together」仙台大会、テレビ放映情報決定！ | date=February 20, 2012 | accessdate=September 8, 2013 | work=[[New Japan Pro-Wrestling]] | language=Japanese}} The second All Together event featured outside participation from [[The Great Sasuke]], [[Jinsei Shinzaki]], [[Kenoh]] and [[Taro Nohashi]] from [[Michinoku Pro Wrestling]] and Kensuke Sasaki and Katsuhiko Nakajima from Diamond Ring, the recently renamed Kensuke Office. [[Puroresu#Female wrestling|Female wrestler]] and owner of the [[Sendai Girls' Pro Wrestling]] promotion, [[Meiko Satomura]], greeted fans during the intermission. The event featured eight matches and 50 wrestlers. AJPW's [[Kenzo Suzuki|Kenso]] and NJPW's [[Kazuchika Okada]] and [[Prince Devitt]] missed the event due to schedule conflicts.{{-}} ===Results=== {{Pro Wrestling results table |hide=all
