revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; remove 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text: {{Infobox artwork | image_file = The Poem Tree, Wittenham Clumps.JPG | image_size = 220px | title = The Poem Tree | alt = | type = [[Beech tree]] carving | artist = [[Joseph Tubb]] | year = 1844/45 (see [[#Carving|Carving]] section) | height_metric = | width_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | city = [[Oxfordshire]], UK | museum = [[Wittenham Clumps]] | coordinates = {{Coord|51|37|41.66|N|1|10|42.89|W|region:NL_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | owner = [[Northmoor Trust]] }} The '''Poem Tree''' was a [[beech]] tree with a poem carved into it by [[Joseph Tubb]], located on Castle Hill at [[Wittenham Clumps]] in [[Oxfordshire]], [[England]].{{Cite web|title=Poem Tree|url=http://www.earthtrust.org.uk/Our-work/livinghistory/ThePoemTree.aspx|work=The Poem Tree at Wittenham Clumps|publisher=[[Earth Trust]]|accessdate=28 July 2017}}{{Cite web|last=Nash Ford|first=David|title=The Poem Tree|url=http://www.berkshirehistory.com/odds/poem_tree.html|work=Royal Berkshire History|publisher=Nash Ford Publishing|accessdate=16 June 2010}}{{Cite web|title=Joseph Tubb and the Poem Tree|url=http://www.projecttimescape.co.uk/timescape/research/arts/joseph-tubb|work=The Poem Tree at Wittenham Clumps|publisher=[[Northmoor Trust]]|accessdate=16 June 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517120117/http://www.projecttimescape.co.uk/timescape/research/arts/joseph-tubb|archivedate=17 May 2008|df=dmy-all}} The tree, which was believed to be around 300 years old, collapsed through a combination of long-standing rot and inclement weather in July 2012.[http://www.oxfordmail.co.uk/news/yourtown/didcot/9855964.Sadness_as_Clumps_poem_tree_falls/ Sadness as Clumps poem tree falls ''Oxford Mail'' 4 August 2012][http://www.oxfordmail.co.uk/news/yourtown/didcot/9871211.Poet_pens_a_farewell_verse_to_famous_tree/ Poet pens a farewell verse to famous tree by Ben Wilkinson ''Oxford Mail'' 14 August 2012] It died in the 1990s and after that, rotted completely while standing. The poem was carved in the 1840s. A stone, including a transcription and [[rubbing]] of the poem, was erected close to the tree in 1994 to commemorate the 150th anniversary of the carving. ==Carving== Tubb carved the 20-line poem into the tree over two weeks in the summer.{{Cite web|title=Poem Tree|url=http://druidnetwork.org/en/sacredsites/wittenham/poem.html|archive-url=https://www.webarchive.org.uk/wayback/archive/20070123120000/http://druidnetwork.org/en/sacredsites/wittenham/poem.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=23 January 2007|work=Sacred Places|publisher=[[The Druid Network]]|accessdate=16 June 2010}} Taking a ladder and a tent to the beech tree, Tubb carved the poem into the tree from memory, regularly forgetting to take the original copy with him. Sources vary as to whether the carving took place in 1844 or between 1844 and 1845. ==Poem== [[File:Poemtree sample.png|thumb|upright|A close-up of the carving. The word "land" (''The various changes that the land befell'') can be seen, below which the end of the word "country" (''Where the low bank the country wide surrounds'') is legible.]] {{quote|As up the hill with labr'ing steps we tread Where the twin Clumps their sheltering branches spread The summit gain'd at ease reclining lay And all around the wide spread scene survey Point out each object and instructive tell The various changes that the land befell Where the low bank the country wide surrounds That ancient earthwork form'd old [[Mercia]]'s bounds In misty distance see the barrow heave There lies forgotten lonely [[Cwichelm of Wessex|Cwichelm]]'s grave.   Around this hill the ruthless [[Vikings|Danes]] intrenched And these fair plains with gory slaughter drench'd While at our feet where stands that stately tower In days gone by up rose the [[Roman Britain|Roman]] power And yonder, there where [[River Thames|Thames]] smooth waters glide In later days appeared monastic pride. Within that field where lies the grazing herd Huge walls were found, some coffins disinter'd Such is the course of time, the wreck which fate And awful doom award the earthly great.}} ==Inspiration and interpretation== The poem was inspired by Tubb's fondness of the surrounding landscape, which is described in the first half of the first [[stanza]].{{Cite journal|last=Page|first=William|author2=Ditchfield, Peter Hampson |title=Parishes: Little Wittenham|journal=A History of the County of Berkshire|year=1924|volume=4|pages=380–384|url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=62732|accessdate=16 June 2010}} It has been suggested that the poem, which is also a summary of the location's history, was an example of Tubb's repressed creativity — his ambition was to be a [[wood carver]] but was pressured into being a maltster through family tradition. The "ancient earthwork" at "[[Mercia]]'s bounds" may be [[Grim's Ditch]] or [[The Ridgeway]] (the latter is formed by part of Grim's Ditch). At the time of [[Alfred the Great]], the border between Mercia and [[Wessex]] ran roughly in a line from east to west through the region.{{Cite web|last=Keynes|first=Simon|title=Alfred's Kingdom of the Anglo-Saxons|url=http://www.anglo-saxons.net/hwaet/?do=get&type=map&id=mapAlfred|work=Maps|publisher=Anglo-Saxons.net|accessdate=17 June 2010|author2=Piggott, Reginald }} The mention of Cwichelm's (or Culchelm's) grave refers to [[Scutchamer Knob]], a [[Round barrow|barrow]] on The Ridgeway near [[Grim's Ditch]], approximately {{convert|8.5|mi|km}} south-west of the Poem Tree. The barrow was originally known as Cwichelmeshlaew or Cwichelm's Barrow, and is historically recorded as the site at which [[Cwichelm of Wessex]] was killed by [[Edwin of Northumbria]] in 636. Tubb's assertion that the barrow could be seen in the misty distance is plausible; Tim Allen (an Oxford-based archaeologist) suggests that on a clear day the [[Berkshire Downs]] can be viewed from the hills and vice versa.{{Cite web|title=Time Team: Season 11 Ep. 9|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kRZLmA_l9yA|work=[[Time Team]]|publisher=[[Channel 4]]|accessdate=17 June 2010}} The "smooth waters" of the [[River Thames]] refers to the river running through [[Dorchester-on-Thames]], where the "monastic pride" of the [[Augustinian]] [[Dorchester Abbey]] is mentioned. The disinterred coffins may refer to an 18th-century discovery of two skeletons at the summit of Round Hill. The slopes of the two hills were used for grazing, where excavations have revealed remains of buildings (including a possible [[Roman villa]]{{Cite web|title=The trenches Around Hill Farm|url=http://thehumanjourney.net/html_pages/microsites/wittenham_clumps/Excavations_2004_trenches.htm|work=The Archaeology of the Wittenhams|publisher=Oxford Archaeology|accessdate=17 June 2010}}). ==Legacy== In 1965, [[United Kingdom|British]] geographer{{Cite news|last=Venables |first=Stephen|title=Henry Osmaston|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/henry-osmaston-6095810.html|accessdate=16 June 2010|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=10 July 2006}} [[Henry Osmaston]] took a [[rubbing]] of the poem before it became largely illegible. In the 1980s, the health of the tree began to decline and it died in the early 1990s. By the time of its collapse in 2012, the poem had become difficult to read; the few legible letters having been distorted with growth of the tree. In 1994, a plaque and stone were placed nearby to commemorate 150 years since the carving. The plaque, which features a copy of Osmaston's 1965 tracing, is fixed to a large [[Sarsen]] stone. Following its collapse, a crane was used to help make the tree safe but the much decayed trunk disintegrated. A few days later a tribute of flowers including gladioli were left anonymously on the shattered trunk. The remains of the tree have been left in situ to form a natural habitat. ==References== {{commons category|The Poem Tree}} {{Reflist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Poem Tree}} [[Category:Culture in Oxfordshire]] [[Category:History of Oxfordshire]] [[Category:English poems]] [[Category:Individual trees in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:2010s individual tree deaths]]

revision.text:
{{for|the Scottish producers|Theatre Guild Glasgow}} [[Image:TheatreGuildLogo.jpg|right]] [[File:TheatreGuild.jpg|thumb|Directors of the Theatre Guild in 1923]] The '''Theatre Guild''' is a [[theatre|theatrical]] society founded in [[New York City]] in 1918 by [[Lawrence Langner]], [[Philip Moeller]], [[Helen Westley]]<ref>Cody, Gabrielle and Sprinchorn, Evert. ''The Columbia encyclopedia of modern drama, Volume 2'', Columbia University Press, p. 1341</ref> and [[Theresa Helburn]]. Langner's wife, Armina Marshall, then served as a co-director. It evolved out of the work of the [[Washington Square Players]].<ref>''A Pictorial History of the Theatre Guild'' by Lawrence Langner and Armina Marshall. Introd. by Brooks Atkinson. Crown Publishers. 1969</ref>
Its original purpose was to produce non-commercial works by [[United States|American]] and foreign [[playwrights]]. It differed from other theaters at the time in that its board of directors shared the responsibility of choosing plays, management, and production.<ref>''Vintage Years Of The Theatre Guild, 1928-1939'' by Roy S. Waldau. Case Western Reserve University Press. 1972</ref> The Theatre Guild contributed greatly to the success of [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] from the 1920s throughout the 1970s.
The Guild has produced a total of 228 plays on Broadway, including 18 by [[George Bernard Shaw]] and seven by [[Eugene O'Neill]]. Other major playwrights introduced to theatre-going Americans include [[Robert E. Sherwood]], [[Maxwell Anderson]], [[Sidney Howard]], [[William Saroyan]], and [[Philip Barry]]. In the field of [[musical theatre]], the Guild has promoted works by [[Richard Rodgers]], teamed with both [[Lorenz Hart]] and [[Oscar Hammerstein II]], [[George Gershwin|George]] and [[Ira Gershwin]], [[Jule Styne]], and [[Meredith Willson]], all of which have become classics. Under President [[John F. Kennedy]], the Guild was engaged to assemble a U.S. theatre company, headed by [[Helen Hayes]], to tour the capitals of [[Europe]] and [[South America]] with works by [[Tennessee Williams]], [[Thornton Wilder]], and [[William Gibson (playwright)|William Gibson]].<ref>''The Oxford Companion to American Theatre''. Oxford University Press. 2004</ref>
In 1968, the Guild became involved in the travel field by taking 25 of its subscribers to European capitals to see plays. In 1975, it instituted its Theatre At Sea program with a 17-day cruise aboard the [[SS Rotterdam|''Rotterdam'']] with Hayes and [[Cyril Ritchard]]. Since then they have hosted more than thirty cruises, each with seven or eight performers. Among them have been [[Alan Arkin]], [[Zoe Caldwell]], [[Anne Jackson]], [[Cherry Jones]], [[Richard Kiley]], [[Eartha Kitt]], [[Patricia Neal]], [[Lynn Redgrave]], [[Gena Rowlands]], [[Jean Stapleton]], [[Eli Wallach]], and [[Lee Roy Reams]], who served as the program's resident director.
The last Broadway play produced by The Theatre Guild was ''[[State Fair (musical)|State Fair]]'' in 1996.
==Notable productions== *1920: ''[[Heartbreak House]]'' *1921: ''[[Liliom]]'' *1922: ''[[R.U.R. (Rossum's Universal Robots)]]'' *1923: ''[[Saint Joan (play)|Saint Joan]]'' *1925: ''[[Processional (play)|Processional]]'' *1927: ''[[Porgy (play)|Porgy]]'' *1928: ''[[Strange Interlude]]'' *1931: ''[[Mourning Becomes Electra]]'' *1933: ''[[Ah, Wilderness!]]'' *1935: ''[[Porgy and Bess]]'' *1936: ''[[The Masque of Kings (play)|The Masque of Kings]]''; ''[[Idiot's Delight (play)|Idiot's Delight]]'' *1939: ''[[The Philadelphia Story (play)|The Philadelphia Story]]''; ''[[The Time of Your Life]]'' *1943: ''[[Oklahoma!]]'' *1943: ''[[Othello#20th century|Othello]]'' *1944: ''Jacobowsky and the Colonel'' *1945: ''[[Carousel (musical)|Carousel]]'' *1946: ''[[The Iceman Cometh]]'' *1947: ''[[The Winslow Boy]]'' *1950: ''[[Come Back, Little Sheba (play)|Come Back, Little Sheba]]'' *1953: ''[[Picnic (play)|Picnic]]''; ''[[The Trip to Bountiful (play)|The Trip to Bountiful]]'' *1955: ''[[The Matchmaker]]'' *1956: ''[[Bells Are Ringing (musical)|Bells Are Ringing]]'' *1958: ''[[Sunrise at Campobello (play)|Sunrise at Campobello]]'' *1960: ''[[The Unsinkable Molly Brown (musical)|The Unsinkable Molly Brown]]'' *1965: ''[[The Royal Hunt of the Sun]]'' *1974: ''[[Absurd Person Singular]]''
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Theatre Guild}} *{{IBDB name|20920|Theatre Guild}} *[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/590271/Theatre-Guild Encyclopædia Britannica entry] *[http://www.brynmawr.edu/Library/speccoll/guides/helburn/index.shtml Finding Aid to the Theresa Helburn Theatre Guild Collection, Bryn Mawr College] *[http://archives.nypl.org/the/22321 Theatre Guild records, 1949-1952], held by the Billy Rose Theatre Division, [[New York Public Library for the Performing Arts]] *[http://archives.nypl.org/the/21816 Theatre Guild technical drawings and other production materials, circa 1925-1953], held by the Billy Rose Theatre Division, [[New York Public Library for the Performing Arts]] *[http://archives.nypl.org/the/21815 Sara Greenspan Theatre Guild files, 1925-1969], held by the Billy Rose Theatre Division, [[New York Public Library for the Performing Arts]]

page.title: Trial of Nicolae and Elena Ceaușescu

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{infobox | title = Trial of the Ceaușescus | data1 = [[File:Crop-Nicolae Ceaucescu 1978.jpg|110px]] [[File:Elena Ceausescu.jpg|110px]] | data2 = [[Nicolae Ceaușescu]] (left), [[President of Romania|President]] of the [[Socialist Republic of Romania]] since 1974 (and leader of the country since 1965), and his wife [[Elena Ceaușescu]] (right), were executed following a show trial on 25 December 1989. }} The '''trial of Nicolae and Elena Ceaușescu''' was a short trial held on 25 December 1989 by an Exceptional Military Tribunal, a [[drumhead court-martial]] created at the request of the Council of the [[National Salvation Front (Romania)|National Salvation Front]], resulting in the [[Capital punishment in Romania|death sentence]] and [[execution]] of former [[President of Romania|Romanian President]] and [[General Secretary of the Romanian Communist Party|Romanian Communist Party General Secretary]], [[Nicolae Ceaușescu]], and his wife, [[Elena Ceaușescu]].
Marked by irregularities that are typical of [[kangaroo court]]s and [[show trial]]s, the main charge was [[genocide]]—namely, murdering "over 60,000 people" during the [[Romanian Revolution|revolution]] in [[Timișoara]].<ref name="Burakovski273"/> Other sources put the death toll between 689 to 1,200.<ref name="reuters1990">{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-01-28/news/mn-1255_1_senior-officials |title=4 Top Ceausescu Aides Admit Complicity in Genocide: Romania: They are the first senior officials of regime to go on trial before a military court. The four are said to have confessed to all charges |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=January 28, 1990 |agency=Reuters |accessdate=16 October 2013 |location=Bucharest, Romania}}</ref><ref name="Quigley2006">{{cite book|author=John B. Quigley|title=The Genocide Convention: An International Law Analysis|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZXZ8qMR5YVQC&pg=PA38|year=2006|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-0-7546-8029-1|page=38}}</ref><ref name="Schabas2000">{{cite book|author=William Schabas|title=Genocide in International Law: The Crimes of Crimes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pYptuRHDQPgC&pg=PA392|year=2000|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-78790-1|page=392}}</ref> Nevertheless, the charges did not affect the trial, as the verdict had been already decided before the Tribunal had been created; General [[Victor Stănculescu]] had brought with him a specially selected team of paratroopers from a crack regiment, handpicked earlier in the morning to act as a [[firing squad]]. Before the legal proceedings began, Stănculescu had already selected the spot where the execution would take place—along one side of the wall in the barracks' square.<ref name="Burakovski273"/>
Nicolae Ceaușescu refused to recognize the Tribunal, arguing its lack of constitutional basis and claiming that the revolutionary authorities were part of a Soviet plot.<ref name="Burakovski273"/>
==Arrest== On 22 December, during the [[Romanian Revolution]], [[Nicolae Ceaușescu|Nicolae]] and [[Elena Ceaușescu]] left the Central Committee building in Bucharest by helicopter toward [[Snagov]], from which they left soon after towards Pitești.<ref>Burakovski, p.272</ref> The helicopter pilot claimed to be in danger of anti-aircraft fire, so he landed on the [[Bucharest]]–[[Târgoviște]] road, near [[Găești]]. They stopped a car driven by a certain Dr. Nicolae Decă, who took them to [[Văcărești, Dâmbovița|Văcăreşti]], after which he informed the local authorities that the Ceaușescus were going toward Târgoviște. The Ceaușescus took another car and told its driver, Nicolae Petrisor, to drive them to Târgoviște. During the trip, the Ceaușescus heard news of the revolution on the car radio (by then the revolutionaries had taken control of the state media), causing Ceaușescu to angrily denounce the revolution as a ''[[coup d'état]]''. Petrisor took the couple to an agricultural center near Târgoviște, where the Ceaușescus were locked in an office and were later arrested by soldiers from a local army garrison.<ref name="Burakovski273">Burakovski, p. 273</ref><ref name=dem25dec>{{cite news|last=Demian|first=Sinziana|title=In Romania, Ceausescu's death haunts Christmas|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/europe/091224/romania-nicolae-elena-ceausescu|accessdate=30 March 2013|newspaper=Global Post|date=25 December 2009|location=Cluj Napoca}}</ref>
==Creation of the tribunal== As the new authorities heard the news of their apprehension from General [[Andrei Kemenici]], the commander of the army unit, they began to discuss what to do with the Ceaușescus.<ref name="Burakovski273" /> [[Victor Stănculescu]], who was Ceauşescu's last defence minister before going over to the revolution, wanted a quick execution, as did [[Gelu Voican Voiculescu]]. [[Ion Iliescu]], Romania's provisional president, supported holding a trial first.<ref name="Burakovski273" /><ref name=bbc25dec>{{cite news|title=Ceausescu execution 'avoided mob lynching'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8430213.stm|accessdate=30 March 2013|publisher=BBC|date=25 December 2009}}</ref>
During the evening of 24 December, Stănculescu sent the secret code "recourse to the method" to Kemenici, referring to the execution of the Ceaușescus. A ten-member tribunal was formed to try the case.<ref name=nyt23apr /> The members of the panel were all military judges.<ref name=dak2004>{{cite book|last=Kideckel|first=David A.|title=Death of The Father: An Anthropology of The End In Political Authority|year=2004|publisher=Berghahn Books|isbn=978-0-85745-715-8|page=123|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A3kJQWTZh7AC&pg=PR6|editor=John Borneman|accessdate=31 March 2013|chapter=The Undead:Nicolae Ceauşescu and paternalist politics in Romanian society and culture}}</ref>
==Charges== The charges were published in ''[[Monitorul Oficial]]'' the day after the execution:<ref>[[Monitorul Oficial]], Anul I, Nr. 3, December 26, 1989</ref> * Genocide – over 60,000 victims * Subversion of state power by organizing armed actions against the people and state power. * Offense of destruction of public property by destroying and damaging buildings, explosions in cities, etc. * Undermining the national economy. * Trying to flee the country using funds of over $1 billion deposited in foreign banks.
==Counsel for the defense== The morning of the trial, prominent lawyer [[Nicu Teodorescu]] was having Christmas breakfast with his family when he was telephoned by an aide to Iliescu, and asked by the National Salvation Front to be the Ceaușescus' defense counsel. He replied that it "would be an interesting challenge"<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-01-24/news/mn-769_1_defense-lawyers|title=Ceausescus Expected to Be Rescued, Lawyer Says|first=From United Press|last=International|date=24 January 1990|publisher=|via=LA Times}}</ref>. Teodorescu met the couple for the first time in the Târgoviște "court room", when he was given ten minutes to consult with his clients. With so little time to prepare any defense, he tried to explain to them that their best hope of avoiding the death sentence was to plead insanity. However, the Ceaușescus brushed away the idea. According to Teodorescu, "When [he] suggested it, Elena in particular said it was an outrageous set-up. They felt deeply insulted. ... They rejected [his] help after that."<ref name="auto"/>
==Trial== The trial of Nicolae and Elena Ceaușescu was very brief, lasting approximately one hour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biography.com/people/nicolae-ceausescu-38355|title=Nicolae Ceausescu|website=Biography}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/alan-elsner/trial-and-execution-the-d_b_401497.html|title=Trial and Execution: The Dramatic Deaths of Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu|first=Alan|last=Elsner|date=22 July 2010|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/parallels/2014/12/24/369593135/25-years-after-death-a-dictator-still-casts-a-shadow-in-romania|title=25 Years After Death, A Dictator Still Casts A Shadow In Romania|publisher=}}</ref> Ceaușescu defended himself by arguing that the Tribunal was against the [[1965 Constitution of Romania]] and that only the [[Great National Assembly]] had the power to depose him. He argued that it was a ''[[coup d'état]]'' organized by the [[Soviet Union|Soviets]].<ref name="Burakovski273" />
Nicolae and Elena Ceaușescu were convicted on all charges and condemned to death in a [[Moscow Trials|Stalinist-style trial]].<ref name=impreuna /> At one point, their forcibly-assigned lawyers abandoned their clients' [[legal defense|defense]] and joined with the [[prosecutor]], accusing them of [[capital crime]]s instead of defending them.<ref name=ceausescustenogram>[[:s:ro:Stenograma procesului Ceaușescu]], translated at [[:s:Transcript of the closed trial of Nicolae and Elena Ceauşescu]].</ref> No [[offer of proof]] was made for the Ceaușescus' alleged [[crime]]s. They were tried based on references, solely by offense-name or [[hearsay]], to criminal acts they had committed in the opinion of prosecutors, or as alleged in press reports. Various irregularities presented themselves, or became apparent post-trial:<ref name=impreuna>[http://adevarul.ro/sfarsitul_ceausestilor/Nicolae_si_Elena_Ceausescu-_-Impreuna_am_luptat-sa_murim_impreuna_0_173983015.html Nicolae și Elena Ceaușescu: „Împreună am luptat, să murim împreună!“<!-- Titlu generat de un robot -->] Adevărul, 19 December 2009.</ref><ref name=ceausescustenogram /> * An accusation of [[genocide]] was never proved. Four top Ceaușescu aides later admitted complicity in genocide in 1990.<ref name="reuters1990" /> * The Ceaușescus were accused of having US $1 billion in foreign [[bank account]]s. No such accounts have ever been found.<ref name=impreuna/><ref name=ceausescustenogram /> * Nicolae Ceaușescu openly disavowed the court. One of the Ceaușescus' [[lawyer]]s suggested before the execution that since the pair did not [[legal recognition|recognize]] the tribunal, there was no avenue for appealing the verdict.<ref name=impreuna /><ref name=ceausescustenogram /> * The judges' [[verdict]] allowed for [[appeal]]ing to a [[appellate court|higher court]]. However, the Ceaușescus were executed around five minutes after the verdict, rendering that provision moot.<ref name=impreuna/><ref name=ceausescustenogram /> * The person who signed the [[decree]] for organizing the court, [[coup d'état|coup]] leader [[Ion Iliescu]], lacked legal power to do so. The order actually was handwritten in a lavatory in the [[Romanian Department of Defense]].<ref>Ionuţ Ţene [http://www.napocanews.ro/2010/12/cine-a-ordonat-executia-lui-nicolae-ceausescu.html Cine a ordonat execuţia lui Nicolae Ceauşescu?]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} Napocanews.ro</ref> * [[Romania]]n law prohibited carrying out the [[capital punishment|death sentence]] less than ten days after a verdict to allow time by the defendant's lawyers to file an appeal.<ref name=daysthat>BBC ''[[Days That Shook the World]]'' Season 3, Episode 8, "The Road To Revolution: The Execution of Ceauşescu/The Iranian Revolution"</ref> After the Ceaușescus' execution, the death penalty was abolished in Romania.<ref>Stanislaw Frankowski, "Post-Communist Europe", in Hodgkinson, Peter and Rutherford, Andrew. ''Capital Punishment: Global Issues and Prospects''. Waterside Press (1996), {{ISBN|1-872870-32-5}}. p. 224.</ref> * The coup leaders said the execution of the Ceaușescus was necessary to stop [[terrorist]]s from attacking the new political order. However, no terrorists or [[terrorist cell]]s were found to have been active in Romania.<ref>R.M. [http://revistapresei.hotnews.ro/stiri-radio_tv-8145193-dan-voinea-nu-existat-teroristi-decembrie-39-89-sotii-ceausescu-fost-ucisi-pentru-salva-administratia-comunista-care-dureaza-azi.htm Dan Voinea: Nu au existat teroristi in decembrie '89. Sotii Ceausescu au fost ucisi pentru a salva administratia comunista, care dureaza si azi] Hotnews.ro</ref> * Initially Iliescu did not wish to carry out the executions immediately, and he instead favored a formal trial to be carried out several weeks later.<ref>Peter Siani-Davies [https://books.google.com/books?id=vBssmkvaSoQC&pg=PA136&lpg=PA136&dq=Iliescu+civil+trial&source=bl&ots=Y-UmaosqNU&sig=vI_bdD1d_sawatnKh6Cif55Bwds&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xtDyUvmjFeW-sQTzxoLoCQ&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Iliescu%20civil%20trial&f=false The Romanian Revolution of December 1989] Googlebooks.com</ref> General [[Victor Stănculescu]] insisted on the couple's hasty [[firing squad|execution]] as an imperative for the [[Romanian Army]] supporting the newly created National Salvation Front.<ref name=daysthat /> After a few hours of debating this option, Iliescu agreed with Stănculescu and signed the decree for organizing the court.<ref name=daysthat />
Before the execution, Nicolae Ceaușescu declared, "We could have been shot without having this masquerade!"<ref name=impreuna />
==Execution== Just after the trial, the Ceaușescus were executed at 4:00 p.m. local time<ref name=gua27dec>{{cite news|title=Television shows last hours of the 'anti-Christ'|url=http://century.guardian.co.uk/1980-1989/Story/0,6051,110504,00.html|accessdate=30 March 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=27 December 1989}}</ref> at a military base outside [[Bucharest]] on 25 December 1989.<ref name=nyt23apr>{{cite news|title=Ceausescu Wept as He Faced Firing Squad, Footage Shows|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/23/world/evolution-in-europe-ceausescu-wept-as-he-faced-firing-squad-footage-shows.html|accessdate=30 March 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=23 April 1990|agency=AP}}</ref> The execution was carried out by a firing squad consisting of elite paratroop regiment soldiers: Captain Ionel Boeru, Sergeant-Major Georghin Octavian and Dorin-Marian Cirlan, while reportedly hundreds of others also volunteered.<ref name=theday23janu>{{cite news|title=120 bullets found in Ceausescus|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gAghAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fHYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2040,4327503&dq=execution+of+nicolae+and+elena+ceau%C5%9Fescu&hl=en|accessdate=30 March 2013|newspaper=The Day|date=23 January 1990}}</ref> The Ceaușescus' hands were tied by four soldiers before the execution.<ref name=els23dec>{{cite news|last=Elsner|first=Alan|title=Trial and Execution: The Dramatic Deaths of Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/alan-elsner/trial-and-execution-the-d_b_401497.html|accessdate=30 March 2013|newspaper=The Huffington Post|date=23 December 2009}}</ref> [[Popular history]] author [[Simon Sebag Montefiore]] has claimed that, before the sentences were carried out, Elena Ceaușescu screamed, "You sons of bitches!" while being led outside and lined up against the wall; at the same time Nicolae Ceaușescu sang [[The Internationale]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Montefiore|first=Simon Sebag|title=101 Villains from Vlad the Impaler to Adolf Hitler: History's Monsters|year=2008|publisher=Metro Books|isbn=978-1-4351-0937-7|page=274}}</ref> The firing squad began shooting as soon as the two were in position against a wall. In 1990, a member of the [[National Salvation Front (Romania)|National Salvation Front]] reported that 120 bullets were found in the couple's bodies.<ref name=theday23janu/> The firing happened too soon for the film crew covering the events to record it in full; only the last round of shots was filmed. Others believe the shooting recorded in the trial footage was not from the actual execution but was staged afterwards, with soldiers firing a few more rounds into the corpses a second time, just for the camera. This was probably done to give the footage a more dramatic "climax" since the moment of the actual execution was missed by the film crew.
As the dust settled the cameraman, still filming, was seen walking towards the couple's bodies. Elena had fallen to her right while Nicolae had collapsed where he was. A soldier and a medical doctor then began to approach the bodies to confirm that the Ceaușescus had in fact been successfully executed. The cameraman requested that her blood soaked scarf which had fallen across Elena's head be lifted so her face could be clearly filmed. Similarly, while the doctor was confirming Nicolae Ceaușescu's death he was asked to lift up his head for the camera as well.
In 1989, Prime Minister [[Petre Roman]] told French television that the execution was carried out quickly due to rumors that loyalists would rescue the couple.<ref name=gua27dec />
After the execution, the bodies were covered with canvas. The Ceaușescus' corpses were flown to Bucharest and buried five days later in Ghencea Cemetery on 30 December 1989.
The hasty trial and the images of the dead Ceaușescus were videotaped and the footage promptly released in numerous western countries two days after the execution.<ref name=bbconthis>{{cite news|title=On this day|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/december/25/newsid_2542000/2542623.stm|accessdate=30 March 2013|newspaper=BBC}}</ref> Later that day, it was also shown on Romanian television.<ref name=bbconthis /> The Ceaușescus were the last people to be executed in Romania before the abolition of capital punishment on 7 January 1990.
==Reactions== [[Valentin Ceauşescu]], elder son of the Ceauşescus, argued in 2009 that the revolutionary forces should have killed his parents when they had arrested them on 22 December since they did not need any trial.<ref name=kpost24dec>{{cite news|title=Ceausescu fooled by aides, son says|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/world/ceausescu-fooled-by-aides-son-says-55826.html|accessdate=30 March 2013|newspaper=Kyiv Post|date=24 December 2009}}</ref> After making vague comments about the incident, Iliescu stated that it was "quite shameful, but necessary".<ref name=dem25dec/> In a similar vein, Stănculescu told the BBC in 2009 that the trial was "not just, but it was necessary" because the alternative would have been seeing Nicolae [[Lynching|lynched]] on the streets of Bucharest.<ref name=bbc25dec />
Several countries criticized the new rulers of Romania after the execution due to lack of public trial. The [[United States]] was the most prominent critic of the trial, stating: "We regret the trial did not take place in an open and public fashion."<ref name=gua27dec />
==Notes== {{reflist|33em}}
==References== * {{cite book|author=Adam Burakovski|title=Dictatura lui Nicolae Ceaușescu, 1965-1989 - Geniul Carpaților|year=2011|publisher=[[Polirom]]|isbn=978-973-46-1963-4}} ==External links== *{{wikisource-inline|Transcript of the closed trial of Nicolae and Elena Ceauşescu}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Trial of Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu}} [[Category:1989 in law]] [[Category:1989 in Romania]] [[Category:1980s trials]] [[Category:Abuse of the legal system]] [[Category:December 1989 events in Europe]] [[Category:Events at Christmas]] [[Category:Filmed executions|Ceausescu]] [[Category:History of Târgoviște]] [[Category:Nicolae Ceaușescu]] [[Category:Romanian Revolution]] [[Category:Trials of political people]] [[Category:Trials in Romania]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Donald Trump series}} The '''Trump Tower meeting''' took place on June 9, 2016 in [[New York City]] between three senior members of the [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|2016 Trump campaign]]{{snd}}[[Donald Trump Jr.]], [[Jared Kushner]], and [[Paul Manafort]]{{snd}}and at least five other people, including Russian lawyer [[Natalia Veselnitskaya]]. The meeting was arranged by publicist and long-time Trump acquaintance, [[Rob Goldstone]] on behalf of his client, singer-songwriter [[Emin Agalarov]].<ref name=npr071117>{{cite web |title=Donald Trump Jr.'s Emails About Meeting With Russian Lawyer, Annotated |url=https://www.npr.org/2017/07/11/536670194/donald-trump-jr-s-emails-about-meeting-with-russian-lawyer-annotated |publisher=[[NPR]] |date=July 11, 2017 |accessdate=July 12, 2017}}</ref> It was disclosed to U.S. government officials when Kushner filed a revised version of his security clearance form.<ref name="Met during campaign" />
Donald Trump Jr. made several misleading statements about the meeting.<ref>[http://time.com/5351648/2016-trump-tower-meeting-facts/]</ref> He initially told the press that the meeting was held to discuss adoptions of Russian children by Americans. On July 8, 2017, after news reports stated that Trump Jr. knew the meeting was political, he admitted in a tweet that he had agreed to the meeting with the understanding that he would receive information damaging to [[Hillary Clinton]], and that he was conducting [[opposition research]].<ref name=Apuzzo /> When the ''[[New York Times]]'' was about to report on email exchanges between Goldstone and Trump Jr., Trump Jr. himself admitted that Goldstone had stated in an email to him that the Russian government was involved and that the purpose of the meeting was to get "dirt on Clinton" and that the meeting concerned a "Russian effort to aid the (Trump) campaign."<ref>[https://money.cnn.com/2017/07/11/media/new-york-times-donald-trump-jr-emails/index.html]</ref><ref name="I love it">{{cite news |first1=Jo |last1=Becker |first2=Adam |last2=Goldman |first3=Matt |last3=Apuzzo |title=Russian Dirt on Clinton? 'I Love It,' Donald Trump Jr. said |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/11/us/politics/trump-russia-email-clinton.html |website=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 11, 2017 |accessdate=July 12, 2017}}</ref> In early July 2017, it was reported that President Donald Trump himself drafted Trump Jr.'s initial misleading statement.<ref>[https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/trump-dictated-sons-misleading-statement-meeting-russian-lawyer/story?id=48958619]</ref> The report was later confirmed by the president's attorneys.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/06/02/politics/trump-lawyers-statement-trump-tower-russians/index.html|title=Trump lawyers say he 'dictated' statement on Trump Tower meeting, contradicting past denials|last=Cohen|first=Marshall|date=June 2, 2018|work=CNN|accessdate=29 August 2018}}</ref>
[[Robert Mueller]], the [[special counsel]] of the [[U.S. Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] in charge of Russia-related investigations, is investigating the emails and the meeting,<ref name=Prokupecz>{{cite news |first1=Shimon |last1=Prokupecz |first2=Evan |last2=Perez |first3=Pamela |last3=Brown |title=Source: Justice Dept. probe will look at Trump Jr.'s disclosed emails, meeting |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/07/11/politics/donald-trump-jr-emails-special-counsel/index.html |publisher=CNN |date=July 11, 2017 |accessdate=July 12, 2017}}</ref> and their relation to the [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]].
== Background == Prior to the Trump Tower meeting, Trump campaign advisor [[George Papadopoulos]] met at least twice with a professor who said he had access to "dirt" on Hillary Clinton in the form of "thousands of emails". This occurred before the hacking of the DNC computers had become public knowledge. Papadopoulos later shared this information with at least two other people, including an Australian diplomat to Britain. At a meeting on March 24, 2016, the professor brought along a Russian woman, Olga Polonskaya. Papadopoulos made multiple unsuccessful attempts to set up meetings in Russia between Trump or members of his campaign and Russian officials. He communicated his proposals and interactions to several Trump campaign officials.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/10/30/politics/who-is-george-papadopoulos/index.html|title=Who is George Papadopoulos?|last=CNN|first=Jeremy Herb and Marshall Cohen,|publisher=CNN|access-date=October 31, 2017}}</ref> In October 2017 he pleaded guilty to one count of making false statements to the FBI about his actions. On June 3, 2016, before the public was made aware of potential Russian interference in the presidential election,<ref name=Ford>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/07/donald-trump-jr-russia-meeting/533061/ |title=Why Did Donald Trump Jr. Meet With A Russian Lawyer Promising Information?|work=The Atlantic|last=Ford |first=Matt|date=July 9, 2017|accessdate=July 14, 2017}}</ref> [[Donald Trump Jr.]] was contacted by [[Rob Goldstone]], a British music publicist whose association with the Trumps dates back to the [[Miss Universe 2013]] pageant held in Moscow; at that time, Trump Jr.'s father, businessman [[Donald Trump]], had been co-owner of [[Miss Universe|the pageant]].<ref name=Edelman>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/rob-goldstone-man-behind-trump-jr-meeting-music-publicist-ties-n781931 | title=Rob Goldstone: The Russia-Tied Music Publicist Behind Trump Jr. Meeting|publisher=NBC News|last=Edelman|first=Adam|date=July 11, 2017|accessdate=July 14, 2017}}</ref> Goldstone's client, [[Emin Agalarov]], an [[Azerbaijanis|Azerbaijani]] singer, performed at the Miss Universe event. His father, [[Aras Agalarov]], is a wealthy real estate developer in Moscow.<ref name=Newsweek>{{cite news |date=July 11, 2017 |title=Trump, the Russian Lawyer and the Pop Star: President's Links to Azerbaijan Oligarch Come Under Scrutiny |url=http://www.newsweek.com/trump-azerbaijan-pop-star-russian-lawyer-634932 |newspaper=Newsweek |last=Porter|first=Tom| access-date=July 14, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=July 10, 2017 |title=How a Music Publicist Connected Trump's Inner Circle to a Russian Lawyer Peddling Clinton Dirt |url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2017/07/how-a-music-publicist-connected-trumps-inner-circle-to-a-russian-lawyer-peddling-clinton-dirt/ |newspaper=Mother Jones |access-date=July 11, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first1=Megan |last1=Twohey |first2=Steve |last2=Eder |title=How a Pageant Led to a Trump Son’s Meeting With a Russian Lawyer |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/10/us/politics/rob-goldstone-russia-trump.html |website=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 10, 2017 |accessdate=July 12, 2017}}</ref>
In his June 3 email to Trump Jr., Goldstone wrote:
{{blockquote|1=Emin just called and asked me to contact you with something very interesting.
The Crown prosecutor of Russia{{efn|name=crown|1=Crown prosecutor is not an office that exists in Russia; Goldstone is likely referring to the [[Prosecutor General of Russia]] here. The position has been held by [[Yury Chaika]] since 2006.<ref>{{cite web |first=Veronika |last=Bondarenko |title=Donald Trump Jr.'s emails reference meeting the crown prosecutor of Russia – here's what that might be |url=http://nordic.businessinsider.com/what-is-crown-prosecutor-of-russia-donald-trump-jr-emails-2017-7 |website=[[Business Insider]] |publisher=[[Axel Springer SE]] |date=July 11, 2017 |accessdate=July 12, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Julia |last=Ioffe |authorlink=Julia Ioffe |title=What the Heck Is a Russian 'Crown Prosecutor'? |work=[[The Atlantic]] |date=July 11, 2017 |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2017/07/russian-crown-prosecutor/533295/ }}</ref>}} met with his father Aras this morning and in their meeting offered to provide the Trump campaign with some official documents and information that would incriminate Hillary and her dealings with Russia and would be very useful to your father.
This is obviously very high level and sensitive information but is part of Russia and its government’s support for Mr. Trump – helped along by Aras and Emin.<ref name=read-the-emails>{{cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/07/donald-trumps-jrs-email-exchange/533244/ |title=Donald Trump Jr.'s Email Exchange With Rob Goldstone|last=Alvarez|first=Priscilla|last2=Godfrey|first2=Elaine|work=[[The Atlantic]] |date=July 11, 2017 |accessdate=August 5, 2017}}</ref>}}
Trump Jr. responded:
{{blockquote|Thanks Rob I appreciate that. I am on the road at the moment but perhaps I just speak to Emin first. Seems we have some time and if it’s what you say I love it especially later in the summer. Could we do a call first thing next week when I am back?<ref name=read-the-emails />}}
In a June 7 email, it was agreed that the material would be delivered to Trump Jr. by an unnamed "Russian government attorney".<ref name=read-the-emails /> At the meeting, Goldstone introduced this person as Moscow-based attorney [[Natalia Veselnitskaya]]. She stated that she was not a government official,<ref name=read-the-emails /> however she is known to have ties to the Russian government<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/07/10/536478972/lawyer-who-met-with-trump-jr-has-ties-to-russian-government|title=Lawyer Who Met With Trump Jr. Has Ties To Russian Government|last=Parks|first=Miles|date=July 10, 2017|publisher=NPR|accessdate=July 17, 2017}}</ref> and later described herself as an "informant" to the office of the Russian prosecutor general.<ref name=informant>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/27/us/natalya-veselnitskaya-trump-tower-russian-prosecutor-general.html |title=Lawyer Who Was Said to Have Dirt on Clinton Had Closer Ties to Kremlin Than She Let On|last=Kramer|first=Andrew|last2=LaFraniere|first2=Sharon|work=[[New York Times]] | date=April 27, 2018 | accessdate=May 2, 2018}}</ref> According to Goldstone, she had planned to be in New York for a court appearance on June 9.<ref name = read-the-emails /> Trump Jr. offered an in-person meeting that afternoon, which Goldstone confirmed.<ref name=read-the-emails /> Trump Jr. forwarded the email thread to Kushner and Manafort.<ref name=npr071117/>
== Trump Tower meeting ==
The arranged meeting took place at [[Trump Tower]] in the afternoon of June 9, 2016. At least eight people attended.<ref name="cnn eight people">{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/07/14/politics/donald-trump-jr-meeting/index.html|title=Trump Tower Russia meeting: At least eight people in the room|publisher=CNN|date=July 15, 2017}}</ref> When the meeting first became known, conflicting accounts of who attended circulated. With time, more names came forward. At first, Donald Trump, Jr. did not disclose that [[Ike Kaveladze|Irakly "Ike" Kaveladze]], [[Rob Goldstone]], and Anatoli Samachornov attended the meeting.<ref name="Bertrand_8/31/2017">{{cite web | last=Bertrand | first=Natasha | date=August 31, 2017 | title=Manafort's notes from the Trump Tower Russia meeting reportedly mention political contributions and the RNC | website=Yahoo Finance | url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/manaforts-notes-trump-tower-russia-192213764.html | access-date=September 1, 2017}}</ref>
===Participants=== ====Trump campaign officials====
[[File:Kushner Denies Colluding with Russia.webmhd.webm|thumb|thumbtime=0:14|News report from [[Voice of America]]]] * [[Jared Kushner]], Trump's son-in-law, responsible for the campaign's digital, online, and social media operations.<ref name="Vanity Fair">Fox, Emily Jane (October 27, 2016). [http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2016/10/jared-trump-trump-campaign "Was Donald Trump's son-in-law the evil genius all along?"], ''Vanity Fair''.</ref> * [[Paul Manafort]], campaign manager for the [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|presidential campaign of Donald Trump]] from 29 March 2016 to 19 August 2016. He was formerly a lobbyist.<ref name=Relman>{{cite web | url=http://www.businessinsider.com/who-is-paul-manafort-and-why-is-he-at-the-center-of-the-trump-russia-probe-2017-7 | title=Paul Manafort was in the Russian lawyer meeting with Jared Kushner and Donald Trump Jr. — here's what you need to know about him | publisher=[[Business Insider]] | date=July 14, 2017 | accessdate=July 18, 2017 | last=Relman | first=Eliza | last2=Bertrand | first2=Natasha}}</ref> * [[Donald Trump Jr.]], eldest son of Donald Trump, active in the presidential campaign<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/03/11/politics/donald-trump-son-texas-dinner/index.html|title=Donald Trump Jr. says he misses campaign trail|author=Betsy Klein|publisher=CNN|access-date=May 16, 2017}}</ref> as a key political aide and advisor to his father.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/21/us/politics/donald-trump-jr-skittles.html|title=Donald Trump Jr.’s Skittles Tweet Fits a Pattern|last=Horowitz|first=Jason|date=September 20, 2016|work=The New York Times|access-date=May 26, 2017|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
====Russian lobbyists==== * [[Natalia Veselnitskaya]], a Russian lawyer best known in the United States for lobbying against the [[Magnitsky Act]]. According to the New York Times, in Moscow she is regarded as a "trusted insider" who has argued cases for government agencies and high-profile clients including Pyotr Katsyv, an official in the state-owned [[Russian Railways]], and his son Denis, whom she defended against a [[money laundering]] charge in New York.<ref>{{cite news|last1=[[Jason Motlagh]]|title=Fighting Putin Doesn’t Make You a Saint|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/126760/fighting-putin-doesnt-make-saint|accessdate=July 15, 2017|work=[[The New Republic]]|date=December 31, 2015}}</ref><ref name=NYT-Kramer>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/11/world/europe/natalia-veselnitskaya-donald-trump-jr-russian-lawyer.html | title=Natalia Veselnitskaya, Lawyer Who Met Trump Jr., Seen As Fearsome Moscow Insider | work=The New York Times|last=MacFarquhar |first=Neil |last2=Kramer|first2=Neil|date=July 11, 2017|accessdate=July 15, 2017}}</ref> She has also been an informant in active communication with [[Yury Chaika]], the Russian prosecutor general, since 2013.<ref name=informant /> Starting in 2014, she had worked with Fusion GPS, the firm that was later hired to do opposition research on Trump, to investigate an unrelated money-laundering case involving [[Fusion GPS#Prevezon Holding|Prevezon Holding]], and the "dirt" she brought with her to the meeting stemmed from that work. The work on the Prevezon case, and later on the dossier, were completely separate, and Fusion GPS co-founder Glenn Simpson testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee that they were unaware that Veselnitskaya would meet with Trump campaign members or share anything from the Prevezon case with them.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/trump-dossier-firm-also-supplied-info-used-meeting-russians-trump-n819526|title=Trump Dossier Firm Also Supplied Info Used in Meeting of Russians, Trump Team|last=Dilanian|first=Ken|date=November 10, 2017|work=NBC News|accessdate=June 10, 2018}}</ref> * [[Rinat Akhmetshin]], a Russian-American lobbyist and former Soviet counterintelligence officer suspected of "having ongoing ties to Russian Intelligence",<ref name=Dilanian>{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/russian-lawyer-brought-ex-soviet-counter-intelligence-officer-trump-team-n782851 | title=Former Soviet Counterintelligence Officer at Meeting With Donald Trump Jr. and Russian Lawyer | publisher=[[NBC News]] | date=July 14, 2017 | accessdate=July 19, 2017 | last=Dilanian | first=Ken | last2=Lebedeva | first2=Natasha | last3=Jackson | first3=Hallie}}</ref><ref name=Quigley>{{cite web | url=http://www.newsweek.com/who-rinat-akhmetshin-former-soviet-intelligence-officer-donald-trump-jr-637050 | title=Who Is Rinat Akhmetshin, Former Soviet Intelligence Officer In Donald Trump Jr. Meeting? | work=[[Newsweek]] | date=July 14, 2017 | accessdate=July 19, 2017 | last=Quigley | first=Aiden}}</ref> although he denies it.<ref name=Dilanian /> After the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]], he immigrated to the United States in 1993 and became a U.S. citizen in 2009.<ref name=Helderman>{{cite news |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/ct-trump-jr-russia-lobbyist-meeting-20170714-story.html |title=Russian-American Lobbyist Was Present At Trump Jr.'s Meeting With Kremlin-Connected Lawyer |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |last=Helderman |first=Rosalind S. |last2=Hamburger |first2=Tom |last3=Crites |first3=Alice |date=July 14, 2017 |accessdate=July 15, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-pol-trump-russia-20170714-story.html|title=Soviet Army intelligence veteran attended meeting with Donald Trump Jr. and Russian lawyer|first1=David S.|last1=Cloud|first2=Joseph|last2=Tanfani|date=July 14, 2017|newspaper=Los Angeles Times}}</ref> According to the ''[[New York Times]]'', Akhmetshin has “a history of working for close allies of President Vladimir V. Putin.”<ref>{{cite news |title=Lobbyist at Trump Campaign Meeting Has a Web of Russian Connections |first=Sharon |last=LaFraniere |first2=David D. |last2=Kirkpatrick |first3=Kenneth P. |last3=Vogel |date=August 21, 2017 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/21/us/rinat-akhmetshin-russia-trump-meeting.html }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Pattern Of Hacking Preceded Attendee Of Donald Trump's Camp Russia Meeting |work=[[The Rachel Maddow Show]] |date=August 24, 2017 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3-cqMTTzqGk&index=2&t=2m12s&list=PLDIVi-vBsOEyETRGoRP9y8zhyu6bHl6iK |via=[[YouTube]] }}</ref>
====Other participants==== * [[Rob Goldstone]], the publicist of [[Emin Agalarov]], who said that Agalarov asked him to contact Trump Jr. New York attorney Scott S. Balber, who was retained by Emin and Aras Agalarov, denied that Goldstone's emails accurately outlined the origins of the meeting.<ref name=WaPo-Boburg>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/who-is-rob-goldstone-whose-email-to-trump-jr-on-russia-caused-a-sensation/2017/07/15/8471f520-68c0-11e7-8eb5-cbccc2e7bfbf_story.html|title=Who Is Rob Goldstone, Whose Email To Trump Jr. On Russia Caused A Sensation?|work=The Washington Post|last=Boburg|first=Shawn|last2=Gillum|first2=Jack|date=July 15, 2017|accessdate=July 16, 2017}}</ref> * Anatoli Samochornov, a translator for Veselnitskaya. In the past, Samochornov worked for [[Meridian International]] and did contract work for the U.S. [[United States Department of State|State Department]] as an interpreter. Samochornov is not an employee of the State Department.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/anatoli-samochornov-translator-donald-trump-jr-meeting/ |title=Translator in Trump Jr. meeting identified as ex-State Dept. contractor |publisher=CBS News |access-date=July 16, 2017 |language=en}}</ref> * [[Ike Kaveladze]], a Georgian-American, US-based senior vice president at Crocus Group, the real estate development company run by [[Aras Agalarov]]. Kaveladze's lawyer Scott Balber, who also represents Aras and [[Emin Agalarov]], stated that Kaveladze attended the meeting as the Agalarov family's emissary “just to make sure it happened and to serve as an interpreter if necessary.”<ref name=8th-person>{{cite news |last1=Brown |first1=Pamela |title=8th person at Trump Tower meeting identified |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/07/18/politics/eighth-man-trump-tower-meeting-russia/index.html |publisher=CNN |date=July 18, 2017 |accessdate=July 18, 2017}}</ref><ref name=nyt071817>{{cite web|last1=LaFraniere|first1=Sharon|last2=Goldman|first2=Adam|title=Guest List at Donald Trump Jr.'s Meeting With Russian Expands Again|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/18/us/politics/trump-meeting-russia.html |work=The New York Times |accessdate=July 18, 2017|date=July 18, 2017}}</ref>
=== Purpose ===
Trump Jr. initially told reporters that the meeting had been "primarily about adoptions".<ref name="Met during campaign" /><ref name=Becker /> He then released a statement saying it had been a "short introductory meeting" concerning "a program about the adoption of Russian children".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/07/15/politics/russia-donald-trump-jr-meeting/index.html|title=The ever-changing story about Trump Jr.'s meeting -- what we know|last=Diamond|first=Jeremy|date=July 16, 2017|publisher=CNN|accessdate=July 17, 2017}}</ref> A few days later Trump Jr. acknowledged that he went into the meeting expecting to receive opposition research from Veselnitskaya that could hurt Clinton's campaign, adding that none was presented and that the conversation instead focused on the [[Magnitsky Act]].<ref name="Bertrand_8/31/2017"/><ref name = stunning>{{cite web |first=Callum |last=Borchers |title=Donald Trump Jr.’s stunning admission to the New York Times |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2017/07/09/donald-trump-jr-s-stunningly-incriminating-statement-to-the-new-york-times/ |website=[[The Washington Post]] |date=July 9, 2017 |accessdate=July 12, 2017}}</ref><ref name="gq">{{cite news |title=The Real Story of Donald Trump Jr. |first=Julia |last=Ioffe |date=June 20, 2018 |publisher=''[[GQ (magazine)|GQ]]'' |url=https://www.gq.com/story/real-story-of-donald-trump-jr |quote=According to one of the participants in the meeting, Don began to realize he wasn't going to be handed what he was hoping for. “The light just went out in his eyes,” the participant told me recently. “He was totally disinterested.”}}</ref> Later a statement from Trump Jr.'s lawyer said Veselnitskaya had claimed to have information "that individuals connected to Russia were funding the Democratic National Committee and supporting Mrs. Clinton" but "it quickly became clear that she had no meaningful information".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-07-11/trump-s-son-has-offered-shifting-explanations-for-russia-meeting|title=Here Are Trump Jr.’s Shifting Explanations for His Russia Meeting|last=Sink|first=Justin|date=July 11, 2017|work=Bloomberg|accessdate=July 17, 2017}}</ref> Trump Jr. said he felt the adoption issue was her "true agenda all along" and the claims of helpful political information were a pretext.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/trump-jr-russian-lawyer-what-happened-crimes-legal-name-collusion-steele-dossier-timeline-explained-a7834566.html|title=What happened between Donald Trump Jr and the Russian lawyer? Everything we know so far|last=Wilts|first=Alexandra|date=July 10, 2017|work=The Independent|accessdate=July 17, 2017}}</ref> After learning that the New York Times was about to publish the series of emails setting up the meeting, Trump Jr. himself published the email chain via Twitter, and explained that he considered the meeting to be "political opposition research".<ref name=read-the-emails /><ref>{{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/07/11/media/new-york-times-donald-trump-jr-emails/index.html |title=New York Times story triggered the release of Trump Jr. emails |last=Stelter |first=Brian |publisher=CNN |date=July 11, 2017 |accessdate=August 7, 2017 }}</ref> He summarized the meeting as "such a nothing... a wasted 20 minutes".<ref name=denies-telling />
Veselnitskaya said that she intended to provide allegations to the Trump campaign about a firm connected to [[Bill Browder|William Browder]], a financier who lobbied for the Magnitsky Act. She said that the firm committed tax evasion in Russia and donated to Democrats.<ref name="hill russian lawyer in touch">{{Cite news |url=http://thehill.com/policy/national-security/342109-russian-lawyer-who-met-with-trump-jr-was-in-touch-with-top-russian |title=Russian lawyer who met with Trump Jr. was in touch with top Russian prosecutor |last=Max |first=Greenwood |date=July 14, 2017 |work=The Hill}}</ref> She said in an interview, "I never had any damaging or sensitive information about Hillary Clinton. It was never my intention to have that."<ref name=MSNBC-Simons/> She initially denied the allegation that she was or is connected to the Russian government. At a later date she disclosed that she was in regular contact with the [[Prosecutor General of Russia|Russian Prosecutor General]]'s office and with Prosecutor General [[Yury Chaika]], about sharing information she acquired in her investigation relating to the Magnitsky Act.<ref name="hill russian lawyer in touch"/><ref name=MSNBC-Simons>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/russian-lawyer-who-met-trump-jr-i-didn-t-have-n781631|title=Russian Lawyer Veselnitskaya Says She Didn’t Give Trump Jr. Info on Clinton|publisher=MSNBC|last=Simons|first=Keir|last2=Elbaum|first2=Rachel|last3=Rafferty|first3=Andrew|date=July 11, 2017|accessdate=July 16, 2017}}</ref><ref name=wsjprosector>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/russian-lawyer-who-trump-jr-met-says-she-was-in-contact-with-top-russian-prosecutor-1500063809|title=Russian Lawyer Whom Trump Jr. Met Says She Was in Contact With Top Russian Prosecutor|first1=Brett|last1=Forrest|first2=Paul|last2=Sonne|date=July 15, 2017|newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]}}</ref>
On July 14, Akhmetshin stated in an interview that Veselnitskaya had claimed to have evidence of "violations of Russian law by a Democratic donor", and added that she "described her findings at the meeting and left a document about them with Trump Jr. and the others."<ref name=Helderman /><ref name="Neuhauser">{{cite news|last1=Neuhauser|first1=Alan|title=Report: Documents Were Exchanged in Donald Trump Jr.'s Russia Meeting|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2017-07-14/report-documents-were-exchanged-in-donald-trump-jrs-russia-meeting|accessdate=July 19, 2017|publisher=US News|date=July 14, 2017}}</ref>
=== Disclosure timeline ===
The meeting, which took place on June 9, 2016, first came to the attention of authorities in April 2017, when Kushner reported on a revised security clearance form that he had met with Veselnitskaya.<ref name="dots">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/11/us/politics/russia-trump-emails.html|title=Donald Trump Jr. and Russia: How The Times Connected the Dots|last=Becker|first=Jo|date=July 11, 2017|work=The New York Times|accessdate=July 18, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Met during campaign">{{cite news |first1=Jo |last1=Becker |first2=Matt |last2=Apuzzo |first3=Adam |last3=Goldman |title=Trump Team Met With Lawyer Linked to Kremlin During Campaign |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/08/us/politics/trump-russia-kushner-manafort.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 8, 2017 |accessdate=July 12, 2017}}</ref> On July 8, 2017, ''[[The New York Times]]'' first mentioned a June 2016 meeting with "a Russian lawyer who has connections to the Kremlin", arranged by Trump Jr. and including Kushner and Manafort.<ref name="Met during campaign" /><ref name=Becker /> Later that day, Trump Jr. released a statement calling it a "short introductory meeting" about American adoption of Russian children and "not a campaign issue".<ref name="Met during campaign" /> The next day it emerged that Goldstone had told Trump Jr. that the meeting would provide the Trump campaign with negative information about Clinton, and that this offer was "part of Russia and its government's support for Mr. Trump", without mentioning adoptions or the [[Magnitsky Act]].<ref name=Becker>{{cite news |first1=Jo |last1=Becker |first2=Matt |last2=Apuzzo |first3=Adam |last3=Goldman |title=Trump’s Son Met With Russian Lawyer After Being Promised Damaging Information on Clinton |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/09/us/politics/trump-russia-kushner-manafort.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 9, 2017 |access-date=July 12, 2017}}</ref><ref name=read-the-emails /><ref name=Apuzzo>{{cite web |first1=Matt |last1=Apuzzo |first2=Jo |last2=Becker |first3=Adam |last3=Goldman |first4=Maggie |last4=Haberman |title=Trump Jr. Was Told in Email of Russian Effort to Aid Campaign |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/10/us/politics/donald-trump-jr-russia-email-candidacy.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 10, 2017 |accessdate=July 12, 2017}}</ref> Trump Jr. reacted by acknowledging that he had been expecting information about Clinton.<ref name=stunning /> Over the next few days the identity of the attendees was established.<ref name="cnn eight people"/>
On July 11 Trump Jr. tweeted the entire email chain leading up to the meeting, a few minutes before ''The New York Times'' published it as well.<ref name=read-the-emails /><ref name="twitter statement" /><ref name="nyt transparency trust">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/11/business/media/how-trump-jrs-transparency-erodes-trust-with-the-media.html |title=How Trump Jr.’s ‘Transparency’ Erodes Trust With the Media |work=[[The New York Times]] |first=Michael M. |last=Grynbaum |date=July 11, 2017}}</ref> Trump Jr. stated that he would have preferred to just have a phone call but that didn't work out.<ref name="twitter statement">{{Cite tweet |user=DonaldJTrumpJr |author-link=Donald Trump Jr. |number=884789418455953413 |date = July 11, 2017 |title=Here's my statement and the full email chain}}</ref> He told [[Sean Hannity]] that the meeting had been fully arranged by email, and that he had received no further details by phone.<ref name="Hannity interview">{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/transcript/2017/07/11/donald-trump-jr-on-hannity-in-retrospect-wouldve-done-things-differently.html |title=Donald Trump Jr. on 'Hannity': In retrospect, I would've done things differently|publisher=Fox News Channel|date=July 11, 2017|accessdate=September 8, 2017}}</ref> He would later contradict this statement during a closed-door interview with the Senate Judiciary Committee on September 7, acknowledging three short phone calls with Agalarov prior to the meeting.<ref name="senate-statement">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-jr-says-nothing-came-of-2016-meeting-with-russians/2017/09/07/43f3f2ce-93e9-11e7-89fa-bb822a46da5b_story.html |title=Trump Jr. says he can’t recall White House role in explaining meeting with Russians |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date= July 11, 2017 |access-date=September 7, 2017}}</ref>
On July 12, 2017, President Trump stated in a Reuters interview that he had only known about the meeting for a couple of days, and that "many people would have held that meeting".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-interview-exclusive-idUSKBN19X2XF |title=Exclusive: Trump says he does not fault son for meeting Russian lawyer |work=[[Reuters]] |date=July 13, 2017 |accessdate=July 15, 2017}}</ref> Trump praised his son Don Jr. for his transparency in releasing the emails, and claimed that they were victims of a "political witch hunt".<ref name=TheHill-Balluck>{{cite news |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/341597-trump-furor-over-sons-russia-meeting-the-greatest-witch-hunt-in |title=Trump:Furor Over Son's Russia Meeting 'The Greatest Witch Hunt In Political History' |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |last=Balluck |first=Kyle |date=July 12, 2017 |access-date=July 20, 2017}}</ref><ref name=Fox-Derespina>{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/07/12/trump-tweets-defense-donald-trump-jr-blasts-fake-media.html |title=Trump Tweets Defense Of Donald Trump Jr., Blasts 'Fake Media' |work=[[Fox News]] |last=Derespina |first=Cody |date=July 12, 2017 |access-date=July 20, 2017}}</ref> The same day Trump Jr. denied having told his father about the meeting.<ref name=denies-telling>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-40577248 |title=Trump Jr 'denies telling father about Russian lawyer meeting' |date=July 12, 2017 |work=[[BBC News]] |access-date=July 16, 2017}}</ref> On July 13, Corey Lewandowski was asked on NBC's ''Meet the Press'' why he had not been invited to the meeting. He replied that he was at a Trump rally in Florida on the meeting date, but there was in fact no rally in Florida that day.<ref name="Kruzel_7/14/2017">{{cite web | last=Kruzel | first=John | title=Lewandowski wrong, Trump was in NY on day of Russia meeting | website=PolitiFact | date=July 14, 2017 | url=http://www.politifact.com/punditfact/statements/2017/jul/14/corey-lewandowski/lewandowski-wrongly-says-trump-florida-day-trump-t/ | access-date=August 29, 2017}}</ref> Instead, Trump attended a Trump Victory fundraising lunch at the Four Seasons Hotel in New York, and returned to Trump Tower at 1:02 PM, where he "remained for the rest of the afternoon". According to emails, the Veselnitskaya meeting was scheduled for 4:00 PM.<ref name="Merica_7/12/2017">{{cite news | last=Merica | first=Dan | date=July 12, 2017 | title=Recreating June 9: A very consequential day in the 2016 campaign | publisher=CNN | url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/07/11/politics/trump-campaign-june-9/index.html | accessdate=August 29, 2017 }}</ref>
The July 8 statement by Trump Jr. became controversial in its own right because of conflicting stories about who had written it. On July 11 it was reported that the statement had been drafted by presidential advisers aboard Air Force One on the way home from the [[2017 G20 Hamburg summit|G20 summit in Germany]], and that it had been approved by President Trump.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/341591-trump-signed-off-on-trump-jrs-first-statement-on-russia-meeting |title=Trump signed off on Trump Jr.'s first statement on Russia meeting: report |last=Bowden |first=John |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |date=July 11, 2017 |access-date=July 18, 2017}}</ref><ref name=Parker-20170731 /> On July 12 Trump's lawyer Jay Sekulow insisted that it had been written by Trump Jr. in consultation with his lawyer, and that Donald Trump "wasn't involved in that".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/07/12/politics/jay-sekulow-trump-lawyer-trump-jr-emails-russia-new-day-cnntv/index.html |title=Trump lawyer: President was aware of 'nothing' |last=Wright |first=David |work=[[CNN]] |date=July 12, 2017 |access-date=June 5, 2018}}</ref><ref name=Dolak>{{cite news |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/trump-dictated-sons-misleading-statement-meeting-russian-lawyer/story?id=48958619 |title=Trump dictated son's misleading statement on meeting with Russian lawyer: Sources |last1=Dolak |first1=Kevin |last2=Faulders |first2=Katherine |work=[[ABC News]] |date=July 31, 2017 |access-date=June 5, 2018}}</ref> He repeated these statements on July 16.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/feature/meet-the-press-24-7/meet-press-july-16-2017-n783491 |title=Meet the Press - July 16, 2017 |last=Todd |first=Chuck |work=[[NBC News]] |date=July 16, 2017 |access-date=June 5, 2018}}</ref> On July 31 ''The Washington Post'' reported that Trump had indeed personally dictated, worked on, and released the statement in Trump Jr's name, with claims that "were later shown to be misleading".<ref name=Parker-20170731 /> According to ''The Post'', Trump had "overruled the consensus" of Trump Jr., Kushner, aides, and lawyers, who favored issuing a transparent account "because they believed the complete story would eventually emerge." Some advisors reportedly feared "that the president’s direct involvement leaves him needlessly vulnerable to allegations of a coverup."<ref name=Parker-20170731>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-dictated-sons-misleading-statement-on-meeting-with-russian-lawyer/2017/07/31/04c94f96-73ae-11e7-8f39-eeb7d3a2d304_story.html |title=Trump dictated son's misleading statement on meeting with Russian lawyer|first1=Ashley |last1=Parker |first2=Carol D. |last2=Leonnig |first3=Philip |last3=Rucker |first4=Tom |last4=Hamburger |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=July 31, 2017 |access-date=August 1, 2017}}</ref><ref name=Dolak /><ref name=BBC-170801>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-40786411 |title=Trump 'dictated' son's statement on Russian lawyer meeting |publisher=BBC News |date=August 1, 2017 |accessdate=August 1, 2017}}</ref> The next day, White House Press Secretary [[Sarah Huckabee Sanders]] stated that Trump "certainly didn't dictate, but ... he weighed in, offered suggestions, like any father would do".<ref>{{cite news |last=Nelson |first=Louis |title=Sanders: Trump 'weighed in' on initial statement about son's Russia meeting |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/08/01/trump-sanders-son-russia-statement-241209 |work=[[Politico]] |date=August 1, 2017 |access-date=August 1, 2017}}</ref> In January 2018, in a confidential letter from Trump's legal team to special counsel [[Robert Mueller]], Trump's lawyers acknowledged for the first time that Trump had in fact dictated the first statement put out about the meeting in Trump Jr.'s name, thus contradicting prior representations.<ref name=trumpdictated>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/06/02/politics/trump-lawyers-statement-trump-tower-russians/index.html |title=Trump lawyers say he 'dictated' statement on Trump Tower meeting, contradicting past denials |last=Cohen |first=Marshall |work=[[CNN]] |date=June 2, 2018 |access-date=June 3, 2018}}</ref>
Although Goldstone's emails described Veselnitskaya as a "Russian government attorney",<ref name=read-the-emails /> Scott Balber, formerly a lawyer for Trump and now for Agalarov, said in a July 14, 2017 interview that she had no association with the Russian government.<ref name=CNN-Balber>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/videos/politics/2017/07/14/agalarov-attorney-speaks-out-sciutto-brown-intv.cnn |title=Attorney For Emin And Aras Agalarov Speaks Out |publisher=CNN |date=July 14, 2017 |accessdate=July 14, 2017}}</ref> For his part, Akhmetshin denied having ties to Russian intelligence, and said that the efforts by Veselnitskaya and himself "were not coordinated with the Russian government."<ref name=Helderman /> Kremlin spokesman [[Dmitry Peskov]] said the government didn't know Akhmetshin or Veselnitskaya, or anything about the meeting.<ref name=LAT>{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/politics/washington/la-na-essential-washington-updates-kremlin-compares-the-trump-jr-email-1499872852-htmlstory.html |title=Kremlin Says The Trump Jr. Email Story Is Like A Plot In A Dragging Soap Opera |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |last=Ayers |first=Sabra |date=July 12, 2017 |accessdate=July 15, 2017}}</ref><ref name=AP>{{cite news |url=https://apnews.com/135216fe8c2c459993d5f5740bc67c15 |title=Russian-American At Trump Jr. Meeting Is Ex-Military Officer |agency=[[Associated Press]] |last1=Tucker |first1=Eric |last2=Braun |first2=Stephen |date=July 15, 2017}}</ref> In a November 2017 statement to the Senate Judiciary Committee, Veselnitskaya said "I have no relationship with Mr. Chaika, his representatives and his institutions other than those related to my professional functions as a lawyer."<ref name=informant /> However she also stated in April 2018: “I am a lawyer, and I am an informant,” adding that "since 2013, I have been actively communicating with the office of the Russian prosecutor general," [[Yury Chaika]].<ref name=informant />
CNN reported on October 9 that Balber had obtained the memo which Veselnitskaya took to the meeting,<ref name="Brown_Herb_10/9/2017">{{cite news |last1=Brown |first1=Pamela |last2=Herb |first2=Jeremy |title=Russians' lawyer says new documents show Trump Tower meeting not about dirt on Clinton |publisher=[[CNN]] |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/10/09/politics/russia-trump-tower-meeting-new-documents/index.html |date=October 9, 2017 |access-date=October 17, 2017}}</ref> and it was released by ''[[Foreign Policy]]''.<ref name="Groll_10/16/2017">{{cite web |last=Groll |first=Elias |title=Here's the Memo the Kremlin-Linked Lawyer Took to the Meeting With Donald Trump Jr. |work=[[Foreign Policy]] |date=October 16, 2017 |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2017/10/16/heres-memo-kremlin-lawyer-took-to-meeting-donald-trump-jr/ |access-date=October 17, 2017}}</ref> The memo claimed that an American firm, [[Ziff Brothers Investments]], illegally evaded tens of millions of dollars in Russian taxes, and contributed to Clinton's election campaign. Veselnitskaya reportedly coordinated this accusation in advance with Chaika, and Putin later repeated the charge.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/27/us/politics/trump-tower-veselnitskaya-russia.html |title=Talking Points Brought to Trump Tower Meeting Were Shared With Kremlin |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |first=Sharon |last=LaFraniere |first2=Andrew E. |last2=Kramer |date=October 27, 2017}}</ref>
Two previously undisclosed emails from Rob Goldstone emerged on December 7, as discovered by congressional investigators. The recipients included Trump Jr., Kushner, and Manafort. In a June 14, 2016 email, five days after the meeting, Goldstone forwarded a news story about Russian hacking of Democrats' emails, describing the news as "eerily weird" in light of what had been discussed at Trump Tower.<ref name="Follow-up">{{cite news |first1=Jim |last1=Sciutto |first2=Manu |last2=Raju |first3=Jeremy |last3=Herb |title=Exclusive: Previously undisclosed emails show follow-up after Trump Tower meeting |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/12/07/politics/previously-undisclosed-emails-after-trump-tower-meeting/index.html |publisher=CNN |date=December 7, 2017 |accessdate=December 8, 2017}}</ref> This discovery contradicted the initial statement by Trump Jr. that "there was no follow up" after the meeting,<ref name="Met during campaign" /> as well as his September 2017 testimony to the Senate Judiciary Committee in which he stated: "Rob, Emin and I never discussed the meeting again".<ref name="Follow-up" />
On May 16, 2018, the Senate Judiciary Committee released emails and text messages in which Trump attorney Alan S. Futerfas provided a prepared statement for Goldstone, Agalarov and Kaveladze, further asserting that it "would be our preference" if they did not say anything else in response to inquiries about the meeting.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.judiciary.senate.gov/download/goldstone-1-exhibits-redacted |title=Goldstone Exhibits, Senate Judiciary Committee |publisher=[[Senate Judiciary Committee]] |date=December 15, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first1=Jon |last1=Swaine |first2=Andrew |last2=Roth |title=Trump attorney fed statement to publicist for Russians about Trump Tower meeting |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/may/16/trump-russia-investigation-donald-trump-jr-senate-testimony |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=May 16, 2018 |access-date=May 16, 2018}}</ref>
=== Reactions === ==== Congressional reactions ==== Democratic Representatives [[Brad Sherman]] and [[Al Green (politician)|Al Green]] sponsored a resolution to impeach President Trump. Sherman argued that Trump Jr.'s emails "add credibility" to the theory that Trump [[Dismissal of James Comey|dismissed James Comey]] as [[Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation]] as an attempt to derail the ongoing investigation.<ref>{{cite web |first=Mike |last=DeBonis |title=A House Democrat has filed the first articles of impeachment against President Trump |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2017/07/12/a-house-democrat-has-filed-the-first-articles-of-impeachment-against-president-trump/ |website=[[The Washington Post]] |date=July 12, 2017 |accessdate=July 13, 2017}}</ref>
On July 10, 2017, the Vice Chairman of the [[Senate Intelligence Committee]], Democratic Senator [[Mark Warner]], stated that "This is the first time that the public has seen clear evidence of senior level members of the Trump campaign meeting Russians to try to obtain information that might hurt the campaign of Hillary Clinton".<ref>{{cite web |first=Pete |last=Grieve |title=Warner: 'Clear evidence' that Trump officials met Russians to get info |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/07/10/politics/mark-warner-clear-evidence/index.html |publisher=CNN |date=July 11, 2017 |accessdate=July 12, 2017}}</ref> Warner also stated that the incident was part of a "continuing pattern" in which Trump officials and members of the Trump campaign have "conveniently forgotten meetings with Russians only when they are then presented with evidence, they have to recant and acknowledge those kind of meetings".<ref>{{cite news |title=Donald Jr's meeting with Russians is "clear evidence" of campaign workings |url=https://www.reuters.com/video/2017/07/10/donald-jrs-meeting-with-russians-is-clea?videoId=372067514 |agency=[[Reuters]] |date=July 10, 2017 |accessdate=July 12, 2017}}</ref> Another member of the committee, the Republican [[Susan Collins]], stated that Donald Trump Jr. and others who attended the meeting should testify before the committee.<ref name=nyt071017>{{cite news |first=Karen |last=Freifeld |title=Trump Jr. was told of Russian effort to help father's campaign: NY Times |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-russia-idUSKBN19V2DO |agency=[[Reuters]] |date=July 10, 2017 |accessdate=July 12, 2017}}</ref> Representative Adam Schiff, the top Democrat on the [[House Intelligence Committee]], described the matter as "a very serious development", and that "It all warrants thorough investigation. Everyone who was in that meeting ought to come before our committee."<ref name=nyt071017/>
Republicans in Congress have been for the most part muted with their comments about the event.<ref name=FT8-ESPN>{{cite web|url=https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/republicans-matter-most-and-they-dont-seem-to-care-much-about-trump-jr/|title=Republicans Matter Most, And They Don’t Seem To Care Much About Trump Jr.|website=FiveThirtyEight|last=Bacon|first=Perry Jr.|date=July 12, 2017|accessdate=July 20, 2017}}</ref> On July 10, 2017, Representative Ted Yoho (R-FL) when asked in an interview if he thought it was appropriate for Trump Jr. to take a meeting with a Russian national, responded that he "probably would have done the same thing” calling it “opposition research".<ref name=FT8-ESPN/><ref name=CNN-Blitzer>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/07/10/politics/ted-yoho-trump-jr-meeting/index.html|title=Yoho: Trump Jr.'s Russian Lawyer Meeting 'opposition research'|publisher=CNN|last=Grieve|first=Pete|date=July 10, 2017|accessdate=July 20, 2017}}</ref> On July 11, 2017, Representative Marsha Blackburn (R-TN) suggested that "the president’s son may have been “duped” into attending the meeting".<ref name=FT8-ESPN/><ref name=FoxVideo>{{cite web|url=http://video.foxnews.com/v/5502905647001/?#sp=show-clips |title=Rep. Marsha Blackburn: Russia Is Not Our Friend|publisher=[[Fox News Channel]]|date=July 11, 2017|accessdate=July 20, 2017}}</ref>
